story:
Click Here for Italian!

We are Michela and Georg, a couple living in Italy. We are desperately trying to find funds to save our 2.5 acres, 85-year-old Single-Vineyard. We have received an injunction from the Regione Piemonte that threatens us to uproot the vineyard within April 1st 2016, otherwise the vineyard will be uprooted by a team of workers at our expenses (plus 3.100 € of fine) and therefore lost forever.

There's not much time left before the deadline, but we are working as much as we can 7 days a week to prevent our vineyard to be cut down! We are halfway with cleaning and cutting the wild shoots and pruning. But the big problem is that we urgently need 500 stakes, new wires and money to go on with our task! If we don't get funding in the next 3 weeks, all the work we are doing right now is just good for unprooting, not for saving.

But here is the story from the beginning:

Michela works from home as an editor for a publishing company, Georg teaches German part time as a Lecturer at Torino University and does some writing for children and translations.

4 years ago we bought half of an old farmhouse in Moncucco Torinese, nestled in the hills of Monferrato 30 km south-east of Torino. These rolling hills form a wonderful landscape and are full of wine and history. So far we have managed to renovate only a part of our farmhouse but we had to stop any further work simply because the money is tight.

Together with the farmhouse came 2.5 acres of an old vineyard that produces Freisa-wine.

Here you find an interesting article in English about Freisa.

A living example of bio-diversity

The vineyard was planted at the very end of the 1920's and therefore is amongst the oldest implants of vineyards in the whole region. Some of the single roots contain genoma that today are either extremely rare to find or have not been mapped before. Therefore, this vineyard is a symbol of bio-diversity, but it risks to be uprooted by law..

The vineyard came as part of the property but we didn't know anything about vineyards and wine-making. For some 20 years a farmer had leased the vineyard for a low annual fee from the old house-owner, doing all the work and selling the grapes to the "Cantina Sociale" (wine-cooperative) of Castelnuovo Don Bosco. He agreed on keeping things the way they were with the previous owners and we signed the contract. So we figured we'd have plenty of time to deal with the vineyard after the renovation of the house. But after we moved in, it was clear that the farmer was letting the vineyard gradually slip out of control. He simply was getting too old to keep a vineyard in shape. You have to prune and tie each plant with great care, replace rotten stakes with new ones and keep the wires in shape. Once the stakes start to tilt, a tractor can't get in between the rows and at once the whole vineyard gets out of control very fast.

The picture below was taken when we started the work on the house. Even if you don't know much about vineyards, you can clearly see how badly all stakes were tilted and that weeds were growing between the roots.


The old farmer told us he hadn't felt well lately and needed to retire. What a blow. We had to take a decision, and fast. No farmer nearby was willing to step in, considering the state the vineyard was in. We called friends, searched for experts on vineyard-farming, met a number of people and asked for their opinion. After long discussions we decided to take on the work ourselves. We knew it would be a hard task. We had no idea how hard it would have been...

This is a detail how parts of the vineyard looked 3 years ago!



In the pic above you see the terrible shape the stakes and the weeds are in the part of the vineyard we couldn't get under control.

The "good" part is getting in shape with a little help from a friend.


Here you see what a battle it is to get things under control once you allow wild trees and bushes to grow!


A stroke of luck

Amongst many others, we talked to Mario Casalegno, (a professional wine-maker with a degree in viticulture and "agrotecnico"). He came to look at our vineyard and was thrilled by the age of the vines, the wonderful exposure and soil, that would guarantee excellent wine. He said he would help us as much as possible (for free in the first season) with the tasks of the vineyard, come by with his tractor for the necessary treatments against major grape diseases, for the milling and to help us keep the expenses to a minimum. Most of all, Mario said he would do the wine-making in his professional cellar... not for money, but in return for a little bit of our wine. Because he is a professional wine-maker and undergoes quality control, the location of our vineyard and his wine-making will mean that our wine will have the official Italian and international registered designation of origin (D.O.C). But most of all, it's top quality-wine.

So that was a new start with high hopes...

Michela is very good at pruning!

What we have done so far

We are now into our third year. The good news is that we managed to clean and maintain more than a fourth of the whole vineyard. Mario came over many times and explained every step. It was no piece of cake, but hard work. For this recovery, we have each put every year more than 500 hours' work in. And the results are:

  1. this first part of the vineyard has been thoroughly pruned throughout the last 3 years, thus verticalizing again the vine-plants, giving them new strength and stamina;
  2. the worst 250 tilted stakes have been replaced, all by hand, mostly replanting the old wooden stakes in new holes about a meter deep. We bought approximately 120 second-hand stakes to replace the worst;
  3. all missing/old wires were replaced by new ones (there are 4 wires running between the stakes);
  4. we cut and uprooted hundreds of small trees that had started to grow between the rows.
  5. we took care of most of the weeds growing underneath and between the rows by hand and with a trimmer (which is a very important and time-consuming task!);
  6. we did all of the disease-management treatments with a backpack sprayer since no tractor can pass through the rows of the "bad part" of our vineyard.

During harvest 2013 we managed to produce 800 liters (210 gallons) of wonderful wine from the "good part".


Mario concentrating on his old hydraulic press


this is how the "good part" of the vineyard looked like in September 2015


We replanted the stakes (except the row on the right, at that time we were working on it) in the "good part" of the vineyard (the weed was cut with a trimmer shortly after we took the pic).

There is nothing in nature that gets out of control so fast as a vineyard, and if you don't prune in winter you have no grapes in autumn. The weeds grow fast, the plants grow wild and start crawling in every direction (without production of grapes), the stakes tilt and everything turns into a jungle within a year.


More problems

2014 was an extremely bad year for wine-makers. In spring it started to rain and temperature dropped. And this didn't stop for months. The plants caught grape diseases such as powdery and downy mildew, black rot, phomopsis. (See here for further info). Unluckily the rotten weather didn't stop and it rained every single day until harvest time, which was the worst case scenario, simply because you can't treat when it rains. Speaking about bad luck: it was the worst year in vine-making in the last 100 years in Piedmont - and had little to do with our inexperience. Even our 60 tomato-plants died of fungi. Because of the rotten weather, the ministry of agriculture gave authorization for spraying hard-core fungicides. We discussed the matter and preferred to lose our entire harvest rather than use chemicals that alter the plants' DNA and end up inside the wine you drink. Sometimes Nature decides against us, and we had to accept it, even if for us it meant losing sales of more than 900 gallons of wine. That sum would have gone into putting the vineyard into good shape. Mario too had big troubles with his own vineyard, his tractor broke down and he could not help us for over three months.

Losing the complete 2014 harvest

Without fungicides, we watched thousands of bunches of our vineyard rot before our eyes. We didn't even need to harvest, because there was not a single grape left on the branches. What we didn't know was that one of the various diseases that affected our grapes had also crippled the shoots that in spring 2015 would have grown to become future stems, then branches and in the end produce bunches. So we should have used the hardcore treatment after all, even had we decided not to make wine out of our grapes because we had used chemical fungicides.

The consequences of a bad year: bad can get worse

The bad year cost us any income from our wine we had hoped for. Also, the two of us had simply not enough time to take care of such a great amount of work. We did what we could and gave it all the time we had.

If we don't get very lucky, the bad part of the vineyard will be uprooted within this year. Uprooting means that the wires have to be torn away, each and every stake will be torn out and every plant will be cut at least 1 meter below the ground (otherwise they shoot again). All this has high costs and we can't do it on our own. For uprooting you need 5 - 6 men and a tractor for more than a week. And the expenses - some 4.000/5.000 € - would nearly be enough to put our vineyard back to shape.

This would be a terrible blow and not an acceptable solution; this is not the way we want to deal with our vineyard. We know that with Mario's help the vineyard will produce 900 gallons of wonderful wine in two years' time... if only we had the chance to save it. We feel it's important to bring it back on its feet and into production. It's not for the sake of money, but because it is 85-years old and in a perfect histoical position. Yes, it will always produce less wine than modern vineyards, but such a wonderful wine is worth every effort. And that's why we are here asking for your help.

With a bit more money than the uprooting would cost, we can manage to save a whole vineyard, and thus keep it in shape for years to come!

What we will try to do (and the relative costs):

  1. Get rid of the weeds and wild tree-shoots: 2.000 €;
  2. New stakes ( for a reasonably low price): 2.000 €;
  3. New wires: 500 €;
  4. Plant the stakes and fix the wires: 1.500 €;
  5. Pay a farmer with a tractor to do the necessary 6 - 8 treatments in 2016 plus mill between the rows: 1.000 €

Total: 7.000 €

We do not want to get rich. We need at least 7.000 € to get the remaining old part of the vineyard in working shape and producing again by 2017. And we can't even think of planting the new stakes by hand, because we're talking about 500 stakes at least (on a long working day I manage to plant about 10 - 12 new stakes by hand, and fix/change the wires). All this has to be done before the plants start to shoot, which is about the beginning/middle of April. Also, the stakes have to be paid for. The total amount of work is so high that we need at least 1.500 € for two or three specialized farmhands with a tractor who first get rid of the old stakes and then plant the new ones by ramming them a meter deep into the ground with the tractor-bucket. Only afterwards we can put in new wires, prune the plants and tie them to the wires.

Cow dung is good for our organic vegetable-garden. In Italy, actors wish good luck to each other by saying "dung" before going on stage. So maybe this helps our vineyard, too?

What happens if we don't reach the necessary funding?

Should we end up with less than we need to cover all the expenses for the whole vineyard, we will employ the funds for saving the "bad part" of the vineyard. The lesser money we will receive, the lesser of the vineyard can be salvaged (For example with 4.000 € we can modernize only about half of the "bad part"). In this case, part of the expenses of point 1. would necessarily go into the uprooting of the vineyard we were not able to modernize... it's impossible to leave it as it is for one more year.

Here you can see a pic from December '16. Beautiful morning to work in the vineyard! What a difference between the "good" and the "bad" part behind it (looks more like a jungle)! The lower row needs new stakes, that's where I will be going soon.

Depending on how much funds we will receive, we could eventually decide to pay for point 1. and the pruning of all plants of the vineyard (without pruning there will be no future production of grapes) and make at least sure that a tractor can be used between the rows for the treatments. This would leave the problems of putting in new stakes and wires, but the plants pruned, the weeds cut and the milling done by tractor would give us another year's time to somehow buy new stakes, eventually funded in part by the sales of our wine in two years' time. It's going to be tough, but we care for environment and Nature and work our land as much and as good as we can. We planted and keep an organic vegetable-garden that gives us fresh organic vegetables all year round. We also planted fruit-trees and had solar panels installed on our house roof. We are extremely conscious about not increasing the industrial agriculture that makes people believe you can bend Nature at your will, that you can eat whatever you want in every week of the year. We believe in sustainability and try to protect our environment, using the absolute minimum of chemical treatments for our vineyard and the wine, while industrial agriculture with consumer-centered laws alters the equilibrium we should strive to maintain.

Are there other ways to help us without donating money?

It's possible.
One way for you to help us would be coming over to our place in Moncucco Torinese for some days or a week, possibly in two or three, and give us a hand with the work in the vineyard.
What you can do depends on whether you are experienced with pruning or not. If so, Michela would show you how to do it here, because every region requires a different pruning. If not, there are hundreds of stakes to be uprooted and new ones to be planted, old wires to put up, weeds to cut... There are so many things to do...
In this case Mario (who has in his farmhouse a small "agriturismo" would give you free boarding and we would, happily, make sure that you don't starve nor be thirsty!
Have a look at our perks, if you have a little time left.

What happens if the funding exceeds our goal?


Of course we are very concerned about the vineyard every day. There would be other things we urgently need in order to get it really going strong in the next years.
- a small second-hand tractor;
- design and produce state-of-the-art labels for our bottles;
- high-quality empty bottles and quality corks;
- we will go totally organic (more time-consuming and thus expensive).

So, rest assured: nothing will be wasted


At this point we need to talk about Freisa and sketch a short history of wine-planting in our area

Freisa is a very old native red wine, amongst the oldest native wines of this area, mentioned already in the 16th century.

"Freisa can be a wonderful wine with structure, and those typical, intense notes of blackberry, raspberry and freshness. Barrel aging can contribute to such balance."

Paul Balke

DNA researchers discovered that Freisa is the genetic "grandfather" of Nebbiolo, and therefore of Barolo. Nevertheless, in the past 40 years the area dedicated to Freisa has shrunk drastically. In the 70s, phylloxera hit so hard that most of vineyards in Piedmont had to be replanted (luckily ours survived). Most farmers at this point decided to change wine variety, because Freisa, at this point, was the Cinderella of vine-plants; it neither had the high production-rate per acre nor the appeal that Nebbiolo or Barolo were starting to build. Big and medium wine-makers switched to other native grapes that produce 40% more wine per acre with better selling varieties for the fast-growing international customers.

As a result, Freisa has become increasingly rare. Estimations say there are only some 2000 hectares of Freisa left in Piemonte.

It's a questionable victory of modern marketing and mechanization over thousands of small-end medium wine-producers, which means that this excellent, astonishing, full and rich native wine (alc. 12,5% maintaining its wonderful organoleptic qualities well over 10 years in a bottle) is slowly going down memory lane.




Italiano Siamo Michela e Georg e stiamo cercando di trovare fondi per salvare il nostro vigneto di 85 anni e un ettaro di estensione. In caso contrario, verrà sradicato per legge e andrà perso per sempre.

Michela lavora come un redattrice editoriale, Georg insegna tedesco presso l’Università di Torino e si occupa di scrittura per l’infanzia e traduzioni. Quattro anni fa abbiamo comprato metà di una vecchia casa a Moncucco Torinese, 30 km a est di Torino, nelle colline del Monferrato.

Nella proprietà era incluso un ettaro abbondante di un vecchio vigneto che produce Freisa, piantato alla fine degli anni ‘20 del secolo scorso e quindi tra i più antichi impianti del la regione. (Qui potete trovare un interessante articolo sul Freisa e la prima foto è stata scattata a circa 1 km da noi, in direzione del castello di Moncucco Torinese in cima alla collina!).

Inizialmente non sapevamo nulla di vigneti e di vinificazione, ma non sembrava essere un problema: per circa 20 anni un contadino aveva affittato la vigna dai proprietari precedenti, vendendo l’uva alla cantina sociale di Castelnuovo Don Bosco. Quando ci siamo incontrati si è deciso di continuare con l’affitto e abbiamo pensato che avremmo avuto un sacco di tempo per affrontare la vigna dopo la ristrutturazione della casa.

Presto, però, ci siamo accorti che l’agricoltore non stava facendo un buon lavoro, probabilmente per l’età avanzata: le piante non erano potate a dovere, i pali erano instabili e marci, i fili rischiavano di rompersi e alla base di ogni filare cresceva l’edera, folta e indisturbata.

L’agricoltore intanto aveva capito di non riuscire a portare avanti il lavoro per problemi di salute e il contratto è decaduto. Dopo lunghe discussioni abbiamo deciso di fare il passo e tentare di fare il lavoro da soli. Sapevamo che sarebbe stato un compito difficile, ma non avevamo idea di quanto ...

Un colpo di fortuna

Tra le persone con cui abbiamo parlato per avere consigli e dritte sulla vigna, c’è stato Mario Casalegno, agrotecnico con l'hobby di enologia, produttore di vino e proprietario dell’agriturismo Cascina di maggio, a pochi chilometri da casa nostra. La nostra vigna lo entusiasmava: grazie a lui abbiamo capito quanto fosse rara e preziosa una simile combinazione di esposizione, terreno ed età delle piante. Una vigna tanto vecchia non produce in abbondanza, ma in termini di biodiversità è una risorsa da tenere in vita.

Mario ha deciso di aiutarci mettendoci a disposizione il trattore per i trattamenti, le sue competenze per insegnarci i lavori necessari e la sua cantina per la vinificazione, il tutto in cambio solo di una parte del vino che avremmo prodotto. Inoltre, prendendo in carico la vigna, il vino avrebbe avuto la denominazione di origine controllata, impossibile per noi che non eravamo e non siamo professionisti.

Insomma, ottime premesse e grandi speranze, ma nonostante tutto il duro lavoro non siamo riusciti a ripristinare l’intera estensione della vigna: in parte perché ciascuno di noi ha già il proprio lavoro, in parte perché avremmo avuto bisogno di un investimento iniziale che superava le nostre possibilità.

Dopo tre anni, la buona notizia è che siamo riusciti a pulire e ripristinare un terzo della vigna.

Ecco i risultati:

1. questa prima parte del vigneto è stata potata per restituire alle piante forza e vigore;

2. i peggiori 250/300 pali sono stati sostituiti (a mano!);

3. i vecchi fili sono stati sostituiti;

4. abbiamo tagliato e sradicato l’edera e tanti arbusti che crescevano tra i filari e abbiamo tenuto sotto controllo le erbacce;

5. abbiamo fatto tutti i trattamenti necessari contro le malattie, in parte con un piccolo trattore e in parte a mano con un vaporizzatore a spalla (immaginatevi uno zaino che porta 18 litri) là dove il trattore non poteva arrivare.

Dopo la vendemmia 2013 siamo riusciti a produrre 800 litri di vino: niente male.

Perché allora abbiamo ancora bisogno d’aiuto?

La sfortuna qualche volta è dietro l’angolo. Durante i mesi invernali, con l’aiuto di Mario abbiamo potato tutta la vigna e abbiamo continuato a sostituire i pali peggiori.

La primavera e l’estate del 2014 sono state devastanti per la viticoltura della zona: troppa pioggia e temperature troppo basse hanno portato con sé malattie come la peronospora, funghi e muffa. Insomma, l’annus horribilis dell’ultimo secolo. Per questo il Ministero della Salute ha dato il permesso di usare trattamenti antimuffa, una sorta di artiglieria pesante dell’agricoltura che ha bisogno di essere regolamentata per il suo forte impatto sul DNA della pianta e sull’ambiente in generale.

Noi abbiamo deciso di non usarlo, non avevamo nessuna intenzione di bere un vino che non ci avrebbe fatto bene. Una buona scelta per la salute, ma poco lungimirante per le sue conseguenze: nel 2014 non abbiamo avuto nemmeno un grappolo e ancora nel 2015 le piante hanno continuato a risentire della malattia e hanno prodotto molto poco rispetto al loro potenziale.

Il pericolo che vorremmo evitare

La spada di Damocle che pende sulla porzione che non siamo riusciti a lavorare del tutto è la legge: non si può lasciare una vigna incolta, altrimenti viene sradicata e il proprietario deve pagare le spese relative (e nel nostro caso sarebbero dai 3.000 ai 5.000 €!).

Perché allora spendere dei soldi che non abbiamo per rinunciare per sempre a un piccolo patrimonio di tradizione?

Ecco quello che dovremmo fare per salvare la vigna:

1. pulitura completa da infestanti, viti selvatiche e arbusti, e in più espianto dei vecchi pali e rimozione dei fili (dovremmo rivolgerci a un’impresa perché è un lavoro che richiede parecchi giorni e diverse persone specializzate, non potremmo farlo in tempo nemmeno se volessimo): 2.000 €;

2. acquisto di nuovi pali (ammesso che li troviamo a un prezzo ragionevolmente basso): 2.000 €;

3. acquisto di nuovi fili: 500 €;

4. collocazione di pali e fili (anche per questo abbiamo bisogno di professionisti): 1.500 €;

5. trattamenti da fare 6/8 volte nel 2016 più trinciatura tra i filari: 1.000 €.

Totale: 7.000 €

Con questa cifra possiamo ripristinare tutta l’estensione del vigneto, tenendo conto che le piante che abbiamo trascurato nell’ultimo anno ci metteranno un paio d’anni per tornare pienamente produttive. Da questo momento in poi il nostro vino sarà venduto attraverso l’agriturismo Cascina di maggio e in questo modo saremo in grado di sostenere le spese future e, con il passare del tempo, sostituire le piante mancanti.

Cosa succede se non raggiungiamo tutti i fondi necessari?

Ovviamente continueremo a lavorare la parte che già abbiamo rimesso a posto e interverremo sulla parte critica in base alla somma che avremo raggiunto. Più alta sarà la cifra che otterremo, più grande sarà la superficie che salveremo dall’espianto.

Cosa succede se il finanziamento supera il nostro obiettivo?

Sarebbe quasi troppo bello per essere vero, ma sappiamo esattamente cos’altro ci servirebbe:

– un piccolo trattore di seconda mano;

– progettare e stampare le etichette per le bottiglie;

– acquistare bottiglie vuote di alta qualità;

– convertire la produzione al biologico 100 % certificato.

Comunque vada la campagna, metteremo a frutto ogni centesimo.


Infine, per chi avesse poca dimestichezza con il Freisa, ecco una breve storia.

Il Freisa è uno dei più antichi vitigni autoctoni della nostra zona ed è documentato già nel XVI secolo. Le ricerche sul DNA hanno dimostrato che, geneticamente parlando, il Freisa è il "nonno" del Nebbiolo, e quindi del Barolo. Tuttavia, negli ultimi 40 anni l’area dedicata al Freisa si è ridotta drasticamente. Negli anni ‘70, infatti, la fillossera ha colpito l’astigiano così gravemente che la maggior parte dei vigneti in Piemonte fu ripiantata (per fortuna la nostra è sopravvissuta). Molti agricoltori decisero di cambiare varietà di vino, perché il Freisa non ha un grande tasso di produzione per ettaro, né la fama del Nebbiolo o del Barolo. Grandi e medi viticoltori passarono ad altri vitigni autoctoni che producono fino al 40 % in più di vino per ettaro e il Freisa iniziò a essere usato dalle grandi aziende come vino da taglio. Molti piccoli produttori, invece, rinunciarono, vendendo le proprie quote di produzione a grandi aziende. Una quota corrisponde alla possibilità di piantare a vigna una certa superficie di terreno, indipendentemente dalla varietà di vite e dalla localizzazione del terreno. Per esempio: se io compro una quota da un produttore che fa dolcetto d.o.c. ad Alba, posso piantare uve anche scadenti nel mezzo della nebbiosa pianura Padana e farne vino da tavola disgustoso.

In un simile contesto economico e legislativo sentiamo sempre di più l’esigenza di resistere, nel nostro piccolo, all’“industrializzazione” del cibo: non vogliamo bere vini pieni di solfiti, non vogliamo mangiare pomodori a dicembre né carne piena di ormoni di animali che non hanno mai visto la luce del sole. Qualche volta è una scelta impegnativa, ma siamo sicuri che in tanti, ormai, la pensiamo in questo modo.
story_txt:
Click Here for Italian!
 
We are Michela and Georg, a
couple living in Italy. We are desperately trying to find funds to save our 2.5 acres, 85-year-old
Single-Vineyard. We have received an injunction from the Regione Piemonte that threatens us to uproot the vineyard within April 1st 2016, otherwise the vineyard will be uprooted by a team of workers at our expenses (plus 3.100 € of fine) and therefore lost forever.
There's not much time left before the deadline, but we are working as much as we can 7 days a week to prevent our vineyard to be cut down! We are halfway with cleaning and cutting the wild shoots and pruning. But the big problem is that we urgently need 500 stakes, new wires and money to go on with our task! If we don't get funding in the next 3 weeks, all the work we are doing right now is just good for unprooting, not for saving.
But here is the story from the beginning:
Michela works from home as an editor for a publishing company, Georg teaches
German part time as a Lecturer at Torino University and does some writing for
children and translations. 
4 years ago we bought half of an old farmhouse in Moncucco Torinese, nestled in
the hills of Monferrato 30 km south-east of Torino. These rolling hills form a wonderful landscape and are full of wine and history. So far we have managed to
renovate only a part of our farmhouse but we had to stop any further work simply
because the money is tight. 

Together with the farmhouse
came 2.5 acres of an old vineyard that produces Freisa-wine. 

Here you find an interesting article in English about Freisa.

A living example of bio-diversity

The vineyard was planted at the very end of the 1920's and therefore is amongst
the oldest implants of vineyards in the whole region. Some of the 
single roots contain genoma that today are either extremely rare to find or have not been mapped before. Therefore, this
 vineyard is a symbol of bio-diversity, but it risks to be uprooted by 
law.. 
The vineyard came as part of the property but we didn't know anything about vineyards and
wine-making. For some 20 years a farmer had
leased the vineyard for a low annual fee from the old house-owner, doing all
the work and selling the grapes to the "Cantina Sociale"
(wine-cooperative) of Castelnuovo Don Bosco. He agreed on keeping things the way they were with the previous
owners and we signed the contract. So we figured we'd have plenty
of time to deal with the vineyard after the renovation of the house. But after we moved in, it was clear that the farmer was letting the
vineyard gradually slip out of control. He simply was getting too old to keep a vineyard in shape. You have to prune and tie each plant with great care, replace rotten stakes with new ones and keep the wires
in shape. Once the stakes
start to tilt, a tractor can't get in between the rows and at once the whole
vineyard gets out of control very fast. 
The picture below was taken when we started the work on the house. Even if you don't know much about vineyards, you can clearly see how badly all stakes were tilted and that weeds were growing between the roots.


The old farmer told
us he hadn't felt well lately and needed to retire. What a blow. We had to take
a decision, and fast. No farmer nearby was willing to step in, considering the state the vineyard was in. We
called friends, searched for experts on vineyard-farming, met a
number of people and asked for their opinion. After long discussions we decided
to take on the work ourselves. We knew it would be a hard
task. We had no idea how hard it would have been...
This is a detail how parts of the
vineyard looked 3 years ago!





In the pic above you see the terrible shape the stakes and the weeds are in the part of the vineyard we couldn't get under control.
The "good" part is getting in shape with a little help from a friend.





Here you see what a battle it is to get things under control once you allow wild trees and bushes to grow!



A stroke of luck



Amongst many others, we talked to Mario Casalegno, (a professional
wine-maker with a degree in viticulture and "agrotecnico"). He came to look at our vineyard and was thrilled by the age of the
vines, the wonderful exposure and soil, that would guarantee excellent wine. He
said he would help us as much as possible (for free in the first season)
with the tasks of the vineyard, come by with his tractor for the necessary
treatments against major grape diseases, for the milling and to help us keep
the expenses to a minimum. Most of all, Mario said he would do the wine-making
in his professional cellar... not for money, but in return for a little bit of
our wine. Because he is a professional wine-maker and undergoes quality
control, the location of our vineyard and his wine-making will mean that our
wine will have the official Italian and international registered designation
of origin (D.O.C). But most of all, it's top quality-wine.
So that was a new start with high hopes...


Michela is very good at pruning!

What we have done so far
We are now into our third year. The good news is that we managed to clean
and maintain more than a fourth of the whole vineyard. Mario came over
many times and explained every step. It was no piece of cake, but hard
work. For this recovery, we have each put every year more than 500 hours' work
in. And the results are:

this first part of the vineyard has been thoroughly
     pruned throughout the last 3 years, thus verticalizing again the
     vine-plants, giving them new strength and stamina;
the worst 250 tilted stakes have been
     replaced, all by hand, mostly replanting the old wooden stakes in new
     holes about a meter deep. We bought approximately 120 second-hand stakes to replace the worst;
all missing/old wires were replaced by new ones
     (there are 4 wires running between the stakes);
we cut and uprooted hundreds of small trees that
     had started to grow between the rows.
we took care of most of the weeds growing underneath
     and between the rows by hand and with a trimmer (which is a very important and
     time-consuming task!);
we did all of the disease-management treatments
     with a backpack sprayer since no tractor can pass through the
rows of the     "bad part" of our vineyard.

During harvest 2013 we managed
to produce 800 liters (210 gallons) of wonderful wine from the "good part".


Mario concentrating on his old hydraulic press

this is how the "good
part" of the vineyard looked like in September 2015
We replanted the stakes (except the row on the right, 
at that time we were working on it) in the "good part" of the 
vineyard (the weed was cut  with a 
trimmer shortly after we took the pic).


There is nothing in nature that gets out of control so fast as a vineyard,
and if you don't prune in winter you have no grapes in autumn. The weeds grow
fast, the plants grow wild and start crawling in every direction
(without production of grapes), the stakes tilt and everything turns into a
jungle within a year. More problems
2014 was an extremely bad year for wine-makers. In spring it started to rain and temperature dropped. And this didn't stop for months. The
plants caught grape diseases such as powdery and downy mildew, black rot,
phomopsis. (See here for further info). Unluckily
the rotten weather didn't stop and it rained every single day until harvest
time, which was the worst case scenario, simply because you can't treat when it
rains. Speaking about bad luck: it was the worst year in vine-making in the
last 100 years in Piedmont - and had little to do with our inexperience. Even
our 60 tomato-plants died of fungi. Because of the rotten weather, the
ministry of agriculture gave authorization for spraying hard-core fungicides.
We discussed the matter and preferred to lose our entire harvest rather than use
chemicals that alter the plants' DNA and end up inside the wine you drink.
Sometimes Nature decides against us, and we had to accept it, even if for us it
meant losing sales of more than 900 gallons of wine. That sum would have gone into putting the vineyard into good shape. Mario too had big troubles with his own
vineyard, his tractor broke down and he could not help us for over three months.
Losing the complete 2014
harvest
Without fungicides, we watched thousands of bunches of our vineyard rot
before our eyes. We didn't even need to harvest, because there was not a single
grape left on the branches. What we didn't know was that one of the various
diseases that affected our grapes had also crippled the shoots that in
spring 2015 would have grown to become future stems, then branches and in the
end produce bunches. So we should have used the hardcore treatment after all,
even had we decided not to make wine out of our grapes because we had used
chemical fungicides.
The consequences of a bad
year: bad can get worse
The bad year cost us any income from our wine we had hoped for. Also, the two of us had simply not enough time to take care of such a great amount of work. We did what we could and gave it all the time we had.If we don't get very lucky, the bad part of the vineyard will be uprooted within this year. Uprooting means
that the wires have to be torn away, each and every stake will be torn out and
every plant will be cut at least 1 meter below the ground (otherwise they shoot again). All this has high costs and we can't do it on our own. For uprooting you need 5 - 6
men and a tractor for more than a week. And the expenses - some 4.000/5.000 € - would nearly be enough to put our vineyard back to shape.

This would be a terrible blow and not an acceptable solution; this is not the way we want to deal
with our vineyard. We know that with Mario's help the vineyard will produce 900 gallons of wonderful wine in two years'
time... if only we had the chance to save it. We feel it's important
to bring it back on its feet and into production. It's not for the sake of money, but because it is 85-years old and in a perfect histoical position. Yes, it will always produce
less wine than modern vineyards, but such a wonderful wine is worth every
effort. And that's why we are here asking for your help. With a
bit more money than the uprooting would cost, we can manage to save a whole
vineyard, and thus keep it in shape for years to come!
What we will try to do (and
the relative costs):

Get rid of the weeds and wild tree-shoots:
     2.000 €;
New stakes ( for a reasonably low price): 2.000
     €;
New wires: 500 €;
Plant the stakes and fix the wires: 1.500 €;
Pay a farmer with a tractor to do the necessary 6
     - 8 treatments in 2016 plus mill between the rows: 1.000 €

Total: 7.000 €
We do not want to get rich. We need at least 7.000 € to get the remaining
old part of the vineyard in working shape and producing again by 2017. And we can't even think of
planting the new stakes by hand, because we're talking about 500 stakes at
least (on a long working day I manage to plant about 10 - 12 new stakes
by hand, and fix/change the wires). All this has to be done before the plants start to shoot,
which is about the beginning/middle of April. Also, the stakes have to be paid for. The total amount of work is so high that
we need at least 1.500 € for two or three specialized farmhands with a tractor who first get rid of the old stakes and then plant the new ones by ramming them a meter deep into the ground with the tractor-bucket. Only
afterwards we can put in new wires, prune the plants and tie them to the wires.Cow dung is good for our organic vegetable-garden. In Italy, actors 
wish good luck to each other by saying "dung" before going on stage. So 
maybe this helps our vineyard, too?What happens if we don't reach
the necessary funding?
Should we end up with less than we need to cover all the expenses for the
whole vineyard, we will employ the funds for saving the "bad part"
of the vineyard. The lesser money we will receive, the lesser of the vineyard can be salvaged
(For example with 4.000 € we can modernize only about half of the "bad
part"). In this case, part of the expenses of point 1. would necessarily
go into the uprooting of the vineyard we were not able to modernize... it's
impossible to leave it as it is for one more year. 
Here you can see a pic from December '16. Beautiful morning to 
work in the vineyard! What a difference between the "good" and the "bad"
 part behind it (looks more like a jungle)! The lower row needs new stakes, that's
 where I will be going soon.Depending on how much funds we will receive, we could eventually decide to
pay for point 1. and the pruning of all plants of the vineyard (without pruning
there will be no future production of grapes) and make at least sure that a
tractor can be used between the rows for the treatments. This would leave the
problems of putting in new stakes and wires, but the plants pruned, the weeds cut and the
milling done by tractor would give us another year's time to somehow buy new
stakes, eventually funded in part by the sales of our wine in two years' time. It's going to be tough, but we care for environment and Nature and work our land as much and as good as
we can. We planted and keep an organic vegetable-garden that gives us fresh organic
vegetables all year round. We also planted fruit-trees and had solar panels
installed on our house roof. We are extremely conscious about not increasing
the industrial agriculture that makes people believe you can bend Nature at
your will, that you can eat whatever you want in every week of the year. We
believe in sustainability and try to protect our environment, using the
absolute minimum of chemical treatments for our vineyard and the wine, while
industrial agriculture with consumer-centered laws alters the equilibrium we should
strive to maintain.
Are there other ways to help
us without donating money?

It's possible. 
One way for you to help us would be coming over to our place in Moncucco
Torinese for some days or a week, possibly in two or three, and give us a hand
with the work in the vineyard.
What you can do depends on whether you are experienced with pruning or not. If so,
Michela would show you how to do it here, because every region requires a different
pruning. If not, there are hundreds of stakes to be uprooted and new ones to be
planted, old wires to put up, weeds to cut... There are so many things to do...
In this case Mario (who has in his farmhouse a small "agriturismo" would give you free boarding and we would, happily, make sure that you don't starve nor be thirsty!
Have a look at our perks, if you have a little time left.

What happens if the funding exceeds our goal?
Of course we are very concerned about the
vineyard every day. There would be other things we urgently need in order to get
it really going strong in the next years.
- a small second-hand tractor;
- design and produce state-of-the-art labels for our bottles;
- high-quality empty bottles and quality corks;- we will go totally organic (more time-consuming and thus expensive).

So, rest assured: nothing will be wastedAt this point we need to talk about Freisa and sketch a short history of wine-planting in our area 
Freisa is a very old native red wine, amongst the oldest native wines of
this area, mentioned already in the 16th century. 
"Freisa can be a wonderful wine with structure, and those typical, 
intense notes of blackberry, raspberry and freshness. Barrel aging can 
contribute to such balance."
Paul Balke
DNA researchers
discovered that Freisa is the genetic "grandfather" of Nebbiolo, and
therefore of Barolo. Nevertheless, in the past 40 years the area 
dedicated to
Freisa has shrunk drastically. In the 70s, phylloxera hit so hard that 
most of vineyards in Piedmont had to be replanted (luckily ours
survived). Most farmers at this point decided to change wine variety, 
because
Freisa, at this point, was the Cinderella of vine-plants; it neither had
 the high
production-rate per acre nor the appeal that Nebbiolo or Barolo were 
starting
to build. Big and medium wine-makers switched to other native grapes 
that
produce 40% more wine per acre with better selling varieties for the
fast-growing international customers. 
As a result, Freisa has become
increasingly rare. Estimations say there are only some 2000 hectares of Freisa left in Piemonte. 
It's a questionable victory of modern marketing and mechanization over
thousands of small-end medium wine-producers, which means that this excellent,
astonishing, full and rich native wine (alc. 12,5% maintaining its wonderful
organoleptic qualities well over 10 years in a bottle) is slowly going down
memory lane.


Italiano
Siamo Michela e Georg e stiamo cercando di trovare
fondi per salvare il nostro vigneto di 85 anni e un ettaro di estensione. In
caso contrario, verrà sradicato per legge e andrà perso per sempre.
Michela lavora come un redattrice
editoriale, Georg insegna tedesco presso l’Università di Torino e si occupa di
scrittura per l’infanzia e traduzioni. Quattro anni fa abbiamo comprato metà di
una vecchia casa a Moncucco Torinese, 30 km a est di Torino, nelle colline del
Monferrato.
Nella proprietà era incluso un
ettaro abbondante di un vecchio vigneto che produce Freisa, piantato alla fine degli
anni ‘20 del secolo scorso e quindi tra i più antichi impianti del la regione.
(Qui potete trovare
un interessante articolo sul Freisa e la prima foto è stata scattata a circa 1
km da noi, in direzione del castello di Moncucco Torinese in cima alla
collina!).
Inizialmente non sapevamo nulla di
vigneti e di vinificazione, ma non sembrava essere un problema: per circa 20
anni un contadino aveva affittato la vigna dai proprietari precedenti, vendendo
l’uva alla cantina sociale di Castelnuovo Don Bosco. Quando ci siamo incontrati
si è deciso di continuare con l’affitto e abbiamo pensato che avremmo avuto un
sacco di tempo per affrontare la vigna dopo la ristrutturazione della casa.
Presto, però, ci siamo accorti che l’agricoltore
non stava facendo un buon lavoro, probabilmente per l’età avanzata: le piante
non erano potate a dovere, i pali erano instabili e marci, i fili rischiavano
di rompersi e alla base di ogni filare cresceva l’edera, folta e indisturbata.
L’agricoltore intanto aveva capito
di non riuscire a portare avanti il lavoro per problemi di salute e il
contratto è decaduto. Dopo lunghe discussioni abbiamo deciso di fare il passo e
tentare di fare il lavoro da soli. Sapevamo che sarebbe stato un compito
difficile, ma non avevamo idea di quanto ...
Un colpo di fortuna
Tra le persone con cui abbiamo
parlato per avere consigli e dritte sulla vigna, c’è stato Mario Casalegno, agrotecnico con l'hobby di enologia, produttore di vino e proprietario dell’agriturismo Cascina di
maggio, a pochi chilometri da casa nostra. La nostra vigna lo entusiasmava:
grazie a lui abbiamo capito quanto fosse rara e preziosa una simile
combinazione di esposizione, terreno ed età delle piante. Una vigna tanto
vecchia non produce in abbondanza, ma in termini di biodiversità è una risorsa
da tenere in vita.
Mario ha deciso di aiutarci
mettendoci a disposizione il trattore per i trattamenti, le sue competenze per
insegnarci i lavori necessari e la sua cantina per la vinificazione, il tutto
in cambio solo di una parte del vino che avremmo prodotto. Inoltre, prendendo
in carico la vigna, il vino avrebbe avuto la denominazione di origine
controllata, impossibile per noi che non eravamo e non siamo professionisti.
Insomma, ottime premesse e grandi
speranze, ma nonostante tutto il duro lavoro non siamo riusciti a ripristinare
l’intera estensione della vigna: in parte perché ciascuno di noi ha già il
proprio lavoro, in parte perché avremmo avuto bisogno di un investimento
iniziale che superava le nostre possibilità.
Dopo tre anni, la buona notizia è
che siamo riusciti a pulire e ripristinare un terzo della vigna.
Ecco i risultati:
1. questa prima parte del
vigneto è stata potata per restituire alle piante forza e vigore;
2. i peggiori 250/300 pali sono
stati sostituiti (a mano!);
3. i vecchi fili sono stati
sostituiti;
4. abbiamo tagliato e sradicato
l’edera e tanti arbusti che crescevano tra i filari e abbiamo tenuto sotto
controllo le erbacce;
5. abbiamo fatto tutti i
trattamenti necessari contro le malattie, in parte con un piccolo trattore e in
parte a mano con un vaporizzatore a spalla (immaginatevi uno zaino che porta 18
litri) là dove il trattore non poteva arrivare.
Dopo la vendemmia 2013 siamo
riusciti a produrre 800 litri di vino: niente male.
Perché allora abbiamo ancora bisogno d’aiuto?
La sfortuna qualche volta è dietro l’angolo.
Durante i mesi invernali, con l’aiuto di Mario abbiamo potato tutta la vigna e
abbiamo continuato a sostituire i pali peggiori.
La primavera e l’estate del 2014
sono state devastanti per la viticoltura della zona: troppa pioggia e
temperature troppo basse hanno portato con sé malattie come la peronospora,
funghi e muffa. Insomma, l’annus
horribilis dell’ultimo secolo. Per questo il Ministero della Salute ha dato
il permesso di usare trattamenti antimuffa, una sorta di artiglieria pesante
dell’agricoltura che ha bisogno di essere regolamentata per il suo forte
impatto sul DNA della pianta e sull’ambiente in generale.
Noi abbiamo deciso di non usarlo,
non avevamo nessuna intenzione di bere un vino che non ci avrebbe fatto bene.
Una buona scelta per la salute, ma poco lungimirante per le sue conseguenze: nel
2014 non abbiamo avuto nemmeno un grappolo e ancora nel 2015 le piante hanno
continuato a risentire della malattia e hanno prodotto molto poco rispetto al
loro potenziale.
Il pericolo che vorremmo evitare
La spada di Damocle che pende sulla
porzione che non siamo riusciti a lavorare del tutto è la legge: non si può
lasciare una vigna incolta, altrimenti viene sradicata e il proprietario deve
pagare le spese relative (e nel nostro caso sarebbero dai 3.000 ai 5.000 €!).
Perché allora spendere dei soldi che
non abbiamo per rinunciare per sempre a un piccolo patrimonio di tradizione?
Ecco quello che dovremmo fare per salvare la vigna:
1. pulitura completa da
infestanti, viti selvatiche e arbusti, e in più espianto dei vecchi pali e
rimozione dei fili (dovremmo rivolgerci a un’impresa perché è un lavoro che
richiede parecchi giorni e diverse persone specializzate, non potremmo farlo in
tempo nemmeno se volessimo): 2.000 €;
2. acquisto di nuovi pali (ammesso
che li troviamo a un prezzo ragionevolmente basso): 2.000 €;
3. acquisto di nuovi fili:
500 €;
4. collocazione di pali e fili
(anche per questo abbiamo bisogno di professionisti): 1.500 €;
5. trattamenti da fare 6/8 volte
nel 2016 più trinciatura tra i filari: 1.000 €.
Totale:
7.000 €
Con questa
cifra possiamo ripristinare tutta l’estensione del vigneto, tenendo conto che
le piante che abbiamo trascurato nell’ultimo anno ci metteranno un paio d’anni
per tornare pienamente produttive. Da questo momento in poi il nostro vino sarà
venduto attraverso l’agriturismo Cascina di maggio e in questo modo saremo in
grado di sostenere le spese future e, con il passare del tempo, sostituire le
piante mancanti.
Cosa succede se non raggiungiamo tutti i fondi necessari?
Ovviamente continueremo a lavorare
la parte che già abbiamo rimesso a posto e interverremo sulla parte critica in
base alla somma che avremo raggiunto. Più alta sarà la cifra che otterremo, più
grande sarà la superficie che salveremo dall’espianto.
Cosa succede se il finanziamento supera il nostro obiettivo?
Sarebbe quasi troppo bello per
essere vero, ma sappiamo esattamente cos’altro ci servirebbe:
– un piccolo trattore di
seconda mano;
– progettare e stampare le etichette
per le bottiglie;
– acquistare bottiglie vuote di
alta qualità;
– convertire la produzione al
biologico 100 % certificato.
Comunque vada la campagna, metteremo
a frutto ogni centesimo.

Infine, per chi avesse poca dimestichezza con il Freisa, ecco una breve storia.
Il Freisa è uno dei più antichi
vitigni autoctoni della nostra zona ed è documentato già nel XVI secolo. Le
ricerche sul DNA hanno dimostrato che, geneticamente parlando, il Freisa è il
"nonno" del Nebbiolo, e quindi del Barolo. Tuttavia, negli ultimi 40
anni l’area dedicata al Freisa si è ridotta drasticamente. Negli anni ‘70, infatti,
la fillossera ha colpito l’astigiano così gravemente che la maggior parte dei
vigneti in Piemonte fu ripiantata (per fortuna la nostra è sopravvissuta). Molti
agricoltori decisero di cambiare varietà di vino, perché il Freisa non ha un
grande tasso di produzione per ettaro, né la fama del Nebbiolo o del Barolo. Grandi
e medi viticoltori passarono ad altri vitigni autoctoni che producono fino al
40 % in più di vino per ettaro e il Freisa iniziò a essere usato dalle
grandi aziende come vino da taglio. Molti piccoli produttori, invece,
rinunciarono, vendendo le proprie quote di produzione a grandi aziende. Una
quota corrisponde alla possibilità di piantare a vigna una certa superficie di
terreno, indipendentemente dalla varietà di vite e dalla localizzazione del
terreno. Per esempio: se io compro una quota da un produttore che fa dolcetto
d.o.c. ad Alba, posso piantare uve anche scadenti nel mezzo della nebbiosa
pianura Padana e farne vino da tavola disgustoso.
In un
simile contesto economico e legislativo sentiamo sempre di più l’esigenza di
resistere, nel nostro piccolo, all’“industrializzazione” del cibo: non vogliamo bere vini pieni di
solfiti, non vogliamo mangiare pomodori a dicembre né carne piena di ormoni di
animali che non hanno mai visto la luce del sole. Qualche volta è una scelta
impegnativa, ma siamo sicuri che in tanti, ormai, la pensiamo in questo modo.

story:
Disclosure: Please bear in mind that past performances and back-tests do not guarantee future performances. 

WondArts is the Art of bringing crucial inputs together to generate Success.

OVERALL
              I present to you my latest, most sophisticated Investment Robot. This platform will give the opportunity to all the public (beginners and experienced) to put funds in the presented robot and watch their capital being invested automatically. No skills are required to acquire and use the robot since everything is being automated. It is a matter of "plug-n-watch". The robot automatically trades on the foreign exchange market based on an algorithm that we have programmed to optimize the potential of great performance. Once your funds are placed, you will be able to activate or disactivate the robot at anytime, and pick one of the 3 risk aversions we offer: Conservative risk - Moderate risk - Aggressive risk. 
                  You can find below, all the back-tests done over a 5 year period (Conservative risk - Moderate risk - Aggressive) with a virtual $10,000 initial capital.  (no worries, you can enter with a capital as low as $200). The net earnings and all kind of statistics related to it are posted too. Since the robot is at the latest check phase, I am creating this page to raise funds to build a secured way that will allow user to invest their funds in this robot and offer them all kind of functionalities to make it customizable. 
We are not stopping here. Just like this robot, we like growth. we will keep extending the functionalities and provide users with other features of investing such as professional financial analysis (both technical and fundamental), the ability to trade manually...
You can check your balance at anytime by logging in your profile. 

SPECIFICATIONS OF THE ROBOT:

  • The robot operates on the Foreign Exchange market specifically AUD/JPY

  • First of all, the robot only opens one position at a time in order to avoid big losses. 

  • It has an automatic stop loss for every position opened. 

  • The back test shows that the ratio win - loss is 9:1

  • The robot allocate the weight of every trade according to your current capital.

WHAT YOU NEED TO DO: (once you buy a license)


1.    Email us your :
                        + Confirmation of the contribution number

                        + The level of risk/reward desired: Conservative, Moderate, Aggressive

                        + Date at which you would like to activate the robot


2.   We will email you:
                       + The confirmation of the of the risk/reward level picked

                       + The date you chose the the start of the robot

                       + Instructions on how to open the account


3.   Email us: 
                       + Once you have opened the trading account as instructed above, please email us the trading account number


4.    We will email you:
                       + The robot file that you will install easily
                       + Instructions on how to launch,  activate, and deactivate the robot  


5.     Last step: Follow the instruction and launch the robot.


(NOTE: The robot file will allow only one account to be used)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Here are some statistics info about the backtest performances of the three risk models:

-------------------------------------RELEVANT STATISTICS----------------------------------------

                                             CONSERVATIVE risk Model

Initial Capital: $10,000                              Net Capital Gain: $270,775

  Max Drawdown: 6.23%                             Avg. Consecutive W-L Ratio: 9:1
:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::


                                                        MODERATE Risk Model

Initial Capital: $10,000                              Net Capital Gain: $1,391,720

  Max Drawdown: 14.49%                           Avg. Consecutive W-L Ratio:  9:1
:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::


                                                         AGGRESSIVE Risk Model

Initial Capital: $10,000                              Net Capital Gain: $50,954,720

  Max Drawdown: 40.7%                            Avg. Consecutive W-L Ratio: 8:1
:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::



Below are the full reports for the three risk models' back-test, with graphs representing the evolution of the growing capital over the number of trades done:


------------------------------------------CONSERVATIVE--------------------------------------------



--------------------------------------------MODERATE--------------------------------------------


--------------------------------------------AGGRESSIVE--------------------------------------------


Disclosure: Please bear in mind that past performances and back-tests do not guarantee future performances.

story:
Mantle Co.working

/ˈman(t)l/ noun 

The part of an oyster that secretes the calcium carbonate precipitated out into an organic matrix that makes the hard protective shell and often a highly valuable asset, the pearl.

Work should not be lonely, it should be exciting. 

Work should be more than just work, it should be a community. 



Mantle is a co-working space coming to Duling School in the Fondren District of Jackson, Mississippi that brings solo-entrepreneurs, creatives, and small teams together in a work space that promotes free flow of ideas, skills and energy. Working at Mantle provides metro-area entrepreneurs and small teams the office space that is less expensive than traditional offices and more reliable and business-oriented than the coffee shop down the street or your own living room or garage.



Reserve your Membership by purchasing a Mantle Perk on Indiegogo today! 


Break out of the cube and work in a community like this one:

  • Five thousand square feet of shared office space in Fondren - walkable to the best bars, coffeeshops, restaurants, and retail in the Jackson metro area.
  • Plenty of parking if you have to drive to work, places to stick your bike if you pedal your ride.
  • One 1000 sqft lounge area complete with super-plush couches, free coffee, water & snacks; premium tea and a craft beer tap at cost.
  • Two 1000 sqft sit, pop, and start, open-concept classrooms outfitted with large format sharable desks, and lightning fast internet connections.
  • Four full-privacy solo-preneur offices: lockable offices with filing cabinets and a blank space to make your own.
  • Three partial-private booths for having more intimate business conversations with your team are open to all members.
  • Two high-tech small conference rooms equipped with wireless mirroring on a 65 inch flatscreen. One relaxed and one for really getting down to business.
  • One high-tech large conference room equipped with wireless mirroring on two 65 inch flatscreen and video conferencing.
  • Zero: the time you will wait for internet content to load with the fastest internet available with full firewall security both wired and wireless across the entire campus.
  • Mail Handling for having a real business address.
  • Lockers for secure storage of laptops and other items while you leave Mantle for a few hours or overnight.
  • File Cabinets for keeping paperwork and office materials secure like a more traditional office.
  • Keyless access to the Mantle campus available using the Mantle iPhone app (Android coming soon) or keypad access.
  • Campus concierge and inApp chat allow Mantle members to share ideas and skills across the Mantle Community.
Reserve your Membership by purchasing a Mantle Perk on Indiegogo today! 

A First of Its Kind in Mississippi

Mantle is a first of its kind offering in Mississippi. A working model similar to others in metro areas across the United States, co-working has yet to truly arrive in Mississippi. Mantle provides the full package that delivers a co-working space that is just as much about community than it is about simple, sleek office space. Use our on-site concierge or our Mantle App to find other Members that can help you in the business you already have, or the business you don't know that you know about yet!



Mantle's mission is more than just providing a cool, modern place to work. Mantle's goal is to put the creative minds of Mississippi together to help spark a renaissance of new thought and economy in our state. Whether you are a creator, a designer, a founder, an entrepreneur, a sales-machine, a solo lawyer, a law maker, or anything in between, Mantle is set up to provide privacy and professionalism for your small company or team. Plus, Mantle is set up to provide the spark of creative ideas between member and bring potential new business and new businesses to where you work.


See what Fast Company magazine says about co-working: http://bit.ly/107JL81.


Membership Costs + Savings Packages:

Pick a Membership Plan and then Browse the Perks to lock in savings. Purchase a Perk to reserve your limited number Membership. The higher the Perk Price, the more the savings, and the better chance you have on reserving one of a limited number of Memberships. If you do not get a Membership because we over subscribe, we will refund your money. 

Single Membership: $300/Month. 24/7 Access to Mantle Co.working space. 4 Large Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Small Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Fiber Internet Access, Coffee, Fruit, and Concierge Services. 

Related Perks: Reserve Only (To reserve: $10 / Save: $0), Reserve Tee & Conference ($25 / Save $25), Reserve Tee & Double Conference ($50 / Save $50), Grain of Sand Reserve ($100 / Save $215), Pearl Reserve ($200 / Save $430), Black Pearl Reserve ($300 / Save $645), One-Year Pre-pay ($600 / Save $1245), Two-Year Pre-pay: Cost ($2,400 / Save $3090).

Team Membership: $300/Month for the first person, $200/Month for the second, $100 for each additional team member up to 5 total team members.  24/7 Access to Mantle Co.working space for your team. 6 Large Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Small Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Fiber Internet Access, Coffee, Fruit, and Concierge Services.

Related Perk: Team Reserve (To Reserve $100 / Save up to $700).

Private Office Membership: $650/Month. A private, lockable office with a desk, file cabinet and room to have conversation with one other person. 24/7 Access to Mantle Co.working space. 4 Large Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Small Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Fiber Internet Access, Coffee, Fruit, and Concierge Services. 

Related Perks: Private Pearl Reserve (To Reserve $650 / Save $740).

Private Office Plus Membership: $650/Month for a private office,  $100 for each additional team member up to 5 total team members.  24/7 Access to Mantle Co.working space for your team. 6 Large Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Small Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Fiber Internet Access, Coffee, Fruit, and Concierge Services.

Related Perks: Private Pearl Reserve (To Reserve $650 / Save $740) & Add a Team Reserve ($100 / Save up to $400).

Off-hours Membership: $100/Month. 6pm to 6am access to Mantle Co.working space.4 Large Conference Hours per Month (1 hour can be used during Prime Business Hours). Unlimited Small Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Fiber Internet Access, Coffee, Fruit, and Limited Concierge Services.

Related Perks: Reserve Only (To reserve: $10 / Save: $0), Off-Hours & Student Reserve ($100 / Save $200), Student Spring Semester Pre-pay ($300 / Save $300).

Me & My Friends Package: $200/Month. 6pm to 6am access to Mantle Co.working space for up to 4 people. 4 Large Conference Hours per Month (1 hour can be used during Prime Business Hours). Unlimited Small Conference Hours per Month. Unlimited Fiber Internet Access, Coffee, Fruit, and Limited Concierge Services.

Related Perk: Friends Package ($50 / Save $200).

Monthly Locker Rental: $15/Month. Keep your stuff locked up while you go meet client for lunch in Fondren.

Monthly File Cabinet Rental: $15/Month. Keep documents safe and secure for your business with a lockable two drawer file cabinet.

Mail Service: $25/Month. Have a business address and let us keep it sorted for you and your team.


Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help create the first community based workplace in Jackson:

  • Come see us at our open house at Fondren's First Thursday, November 5th and December 3rd. Also, at Fondren Un-wrapped on Thursday, November 19th.
  • Contact us and schedule an appointment to go see Mantle Co.working before it opens to check out the great space and location: mantle@pearlbend.com.
  • Buy a t-shirt above! Then buy a t-shirt for a friend, and family member, and a stranger!
  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign, reach out and touch somebody.
  • Share this Indigogo campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and LinkedIn.
  • Email our campaign to those solo-preneurs, freelancers, and small teams that you know. Send them this link: http://igg.me/at/growatmantle!
  • Send us an email (mantle@pearlbend.com) or visit us on Twitter and Facebook and tell us why you want Mantle to come to Fondren.

Funding and Returns

Reaching both monetary and member goals are essential to starting this awesome offering. Due to the new nature of this concept in the Jackson area, hitting member goals in the pre-pay and reservation stage will show that this community-centric workspace is something that Jacksonians want and need.

Mantle has no obligation to take any funding offers. Any funding offered that is not taken by Mantle will be returned upon closing of the campaign. Returns of raised funds are returned in the following manner due to the type of funding purchased:

  • Pre-pay Grade: If accepted, no advance returns. Returns may be made if a full-year membership is subsequently made by a third party and replaces the pre-paid membership. Returns may be made in monthly payments for the remainder of the original pre-paid term. Non-accepted returns will be made in a timely fashion.
  • Reservation Grade: If accepted, no returns, unless Mantle does not honor the reservation due to capacity limits. Non-accepted returns will be made in a timely fashion.

Other Perks Information:

* Purchasers of more expensive Perks get priority of spot reservations in the chance that this campaign oversubscribes. In cases where two purchasers for the same spot purchased the same Perk with only one spot on the line, the one that purchased first in time gets that spot.

** T-shirt purchases are held for pick-up in Jackson, Mississippi at Mantle. If you would like your t-shirt shipped to you, contact mantle@pearlbend.com after you completed the purchase of your Perk and we can work with you to get you your t-shirt. A warning, though, you will have to pay for shipping.

* Upon completion of the campaign, you will be contacted by Mantle management and will be required to enter first month's membership fee (in addition to your Perk purchase) and sign a contract relevant to the Perk purchased in order to secure your membership. Failure to secure your membership spot following the campaign may result in loss of your payment and your paid Perk, unless membership fully subscribes at 50 regular memberships and/or unless you do not get a spot due to full subscription.


Thanks and we hope to create and shine with you soon!

Christopher & The Mantle Team
story_txt:
Mantle Co.working
 /ˈman(t)l/ noun 
The part of an oyster that secretes the calcium carbonate precipitated out into an organic matrix that makes the hard protective shell and often a highly valuable asset, the pearl.
Work should not be lonely, it should be exciting. 
Work should be more than just work, it should be a community. 





Mantle is a co-working space coming to Duling School in the Fondren District of Jackson, Mississippi that brings solo-entrepreneurs, creatives, and small teams together in a work space that promotes free flow of ideas, skills and energy. Working at Mantle provides metro-area entrepreneurs and small teams the office space that is less expensive than traditional offices and more reliable and business-oriented than the coffee shop down the street or your own living room or garage.



Reserve your Membership by purchasing a Mantle Perk on Indiegogo today! 

Break out of the cube and work in a community like this one:


Five thousand square feet of shared office space in Fondren - walkable to the best bars, coffeeshops, restaurants, and retail in the Jackson metro area.
Plenty of parking if you have to drive to work, places to stick your bike if you pedal your ride.
One 1000 sqft lounge area complete with super-plush couches, free coffee, water & snacks; premium tea and a craft beer tap at cost.
Two 1000 sqft sit, pop, and start, open-concept classrooms outfitted with large format sharable desks, and lightning fast internet connections.
Four full-privacy solo-preneur offices: lockable offices with filing cabinets and a blank space to make your own.

Three partial-private booths for having more intimate business conversations with your team are open to all members.
Two high-tech small conference rooms equipped with wireless mirroring on a 65 inch flatscreen. One relaxed and one for really getting down to business.
One high-tech large conference room equipped with wireless mirroring on two 65 inch flatscreen and video conferencing.
Zero: the time you will wait for internet content to load with the fastest internet available with full firewall security both wired and wireless across the entire campus.
Mail Handling for having a real business address.
Lockers for secure storage of laptops and other items while you leave Mantle for a few hours or overnight.
File Cabinets for keeping paperwork and office materials secure like a more traditional office.
Keyless access to the Mantle campus available using the Mantle iPhone app (Android coming soon) or keypad access.
Campus concierge and inApp chat allow Mantle members to share ideas and skills across the Mantle Community.



Reserve your Membership by purchasing a Mantle Perk on Indiegogo today! 


A First of Its Kind in Mississippi
Mantle is a first of its kind offering in Mississippi. A working model similar to others in metro areas across the United States, co-working has yet to truly arrive in Mississippi. Mantle provides the full package that delivers a co-working space that is just as much about community than it is about simple, sleek office space. Use our on-site concierge or our Mantle App to find other Members that can help you in the business you already have, or the business you don't know that you know about yet!




Mantle's mission is more than just providing a cool, modern place to work. Mantle's goal is to put the creative minds of Mississippi together to help spark a renaissance of new thought and economy in our state. Whether you are a creator, a designer, a founder, an entrepreneur, a sales-machine, a solo lawyer, a law maker, or anything in between, Mantle is set up to provide privacy and professionalism for your small company or team. Plus, Mantle is set up to provide the spark of creative ideas between member and bring potential new business and new businesses to where you work.

See what Fast Company magazine says about co-working: http://bit.ly/107JL81.

story:
The Kuchera's Story

  • Drew Kuchera, Kansas, age 31, CEO at Kucheras BBQ 2009-2016. 
  • I started in 2009 making seasonings from home-grown spices and herbs. These organic seasonings were very popular among friends, family, and local farmers markets. In 2010, I competed against 20 salsa entries and took first place in the mild category and second in the hot category. After winning that contest, my passion for canning food dramatically increased. I perfected each recipe and started making bbq sauce, pickles, salsa, jams, etc. 
  • In 2011-2012, I stocked stores, shipped to 45 states and 10 countries, and was receiving nationwide attention on my quick success. But I failed to keep up with the steady demand for my product, and being only a one-man operation, I had to step back and reevaluate my business plan. I've continued my website sales since then, but am now ready to stock stores again, with a major increase in numbers. 
  • The 2016 plan is to start with 10 stores throughout Kansas. Distribution is already lined up. Each store will stock four varieties of salsa and four varieties of bbq sauce (mild, medium cayenne, hot habanero, and ghost pepper extra hot). After successfully stocking all 10 stores, personally demoing my products at each store, and seeing an increase in demand, I'll move into stocking the Kansas City area stores. I need your help...


What I Need & What You Get

  • $10,000 is what I am shooting for. In all reality, this is very minimal for a start-up business, but I've always been one to start small and work my way up. $10,000 will cover the cost of a small filling machine to increase production time, initial employee overhead, upfront costs for jars/labels/design work/ingredients/kitchen fees/USDA inspection/KSU Food Science testing/etc. 
  • Your contribution to this campaign gives you the chance to experience some of the best quality salsa/bbq sauce you've ever tasted in your life. You'll also be a part of helping my dream come true, seeing my business build and succeed in the years to come. This also allows my current friends and customers to stop paying shipping prices and simply travel to your local grocery store for Kuchera's Products!
  • This campaign is funded in two ways. I'm choosing the flex-funding, so if the $10,000 isn't completely raised, I'll still get the chance to send you products with the lower number of funds generated. Either way, your contribution here guarantees you product for your donation and hopefully we will raise the full $10,000! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • I appreciate that you are even here, simply reading my story and plan. If you're unable to donate, you can also help me out by word of mouth and by posting my website/fan page onto social media sites! 
  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/kucherasbbq
  • Website: www.shop.kucheras.com

story:
Short Summary

Well, it finally happened. The Experiment Comedy (http://www.theexcomedy.com/) has secured a space in New York City to call its own. It’s not the back room of a bar or the basement of some funky restaurant. It is a venue we fully operate and call home: The Experiment Comedy Gallery.

Located at 20 Broadway in the South Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, The Experiment Comedy Gallery— The Gallery, for short — is the headquarters for hot, hip alternative comedy — from standup to storytelling, sketch to improv, and more — in a hot, hip neighborhood that’s been underserved when it comes to affordable live comedy. Ticket prices range from $5 to $15 per person. Some shows are even free. Seven nights a week, 52 weeks a year.

The Gallery also plays host to pop culture-centric art shows, trivia events, comedy classes, web video shoots (like the video you've watched on this page) and screenings, podcast recordings, and more. It’s an all-purpose space for all things funny.

Check out upcoming shows via our Ticketfly-powered ticket site: http://theexcomedy.ticketfly.com/calendar

Follow The Experiment Comedy Gallery on social media:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/theexcomedynyc

Twitter: https://twitter.com/theexcomedynyc

Foursquare: http://4sq.com/1mpFHJ1

Instagram: https://instagram.com/TheExComedy/


What We Need & What You Get

We are currently looking to install needed soundproofing, since we have neighbors who live in the apartments above us, and to cover other build out (a functioning coffee bar in the back) and operating costs, like rent and employee salaries. We're asking for a total of $40,000. If we'd don't each our entire goal, the money raised will be used solely for soundproofing. We don't want to wake folks up when they should be recharging their batteries in order to face another day at work.

In the meantime, we're rolling out shows for everyone to enjoy. Perks include free admission to said shows and events, shoutouts on our podcasts, and a bunch of fun and unique goodies like a customized online dating profile created by one of the local comedians and an entire wall named after you.


The Impact

Your contribution will help shape a venue that is looking to be the home for a diverse array of voices not just in comedy but in entertainment in general. The Experiment Comedy has already launched a successful website that features podcasts, videos, articles, standup albums, and more from women, minorities, members of the LGBTQI communities, as well as straight White men :) Here's a sample:

http://www.theexcomedy.com/the-experiment-comedy-albums/rye-silverman-intimate-apparel/

http://www.theexcomedy.com/the-experiment-comedy-albums/sue-smith-slutty-pretzel/

http://www.theexcomedy.com/the-experiment-podcasts/the-soul-glo-project/

http://www.theexcomedy.com/the-experiment-podcasts/megaboom-radio/


Risks & Challenges

Of course, there are risks with any small business. We're currently in a volatile economy. One way we're trying to solve that problem is by renting our space out to big corporate events and film shoots, which will help cover many of our costs. Being a multi-usable space goes a long way.

We've also partnered up with the live streaming app Meerkat, which will help promote the space to tech savvy smartdevice users; and we've teamed up with Ticketfly.com, a ticket selling website that usually deals with music venues. We're their first comedy venue, and they will be doing targeted promotions on their site and via email to comedy lovers in the New York City area. (Quick note: Ticketfly.com was just acquired by Pandora, the popular streaming music site.)


Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you good people just can't contribute because of financial reasons, but that doesn't mean you can't help. We just need you to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. It can easily be done by using the Indiegogo share tools.

And that's pretty much it!
