story:
Today’s environmental issues are not something we can afford to ignore.

lluvia is a simple and modern way for you to address an issue regarding one of our most precious resources:

 

With lluvia you can help conserve your region’s water supply and reduce runoff ocean pollution by reusing the rain that fell on your roof. It provides a sustainable, secondary source of water.

With continuous severe drought, Los Angeles and other cities in California revised their building codes to encourage rainwater harvesting. In Los Angeles, starting July of 2014, any renovation over 50% required installation of rain barrels. As an architectural design firm located in Santa Monica, we had many modern home projects in the affected areas. When it was time to purchase the rain barrels for our clients, the search was exhausting and frustrating. Somehow the word ‘barrel’ stuck the design of rain barrels somewhere in the Stone Age or a wild west saloon. We learned that most home owners removed these eye-sores after the final inspections. 

So we set out to design a better rainwater harvesting system that any modern home owner can be proud to display in their yards. The design process started with distilling the essence of modern home design: in form, materials, and proportions. Most 'barrels' in the market have a capacity of 40-60 gallons, and the average 2,000Sq.Ft. home would need around 10 of these to meet the requirements. We also pushed it further by integrating filtering technologies to expand the rainwater harvesting system’s applicability: a planter with a self-watering system, an outdoor shower, a water feature fountain with re-circulating pump, and a drinking fountain for pets.

We are at our final stage of engineering and prototyping, and hope to go into production by January of 2017. 

If you contribute to fund our campaign, you will be helping to spread  lluvia in many backyards across the globe, consequently saving millions of gallons of water, one raindrop at a time!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

less than 1% of all the water on Earth  is available and safe for human consumption?

 

 

 

 

 

 

and that California is currently in its fifth year of severe drought?

 

 

However,

1” of rain on a 2000 sq.ft. roof = 1200 gallons of water​

 

 

Los Angeles average annual rainfall = 15”​

...this means around 18,000 gallons flow through that roof every year!

18,000 gallons is enough water for over 900 showers, each lasting 10 minutes
That’s a whole year of showering, twice a day!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

If you share our intentions, please share this on facebook!

Spread the word, it will help us so much!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, all! My name is Chloe, and my business partner (and dear friend) Suzanne and I are in the process of opening a women's clothing and lifestyle boutique in Columbus, Ohio. Before The Sunroom became a shared dream, it was an individual one for myself and Suzanne. After meeting we became fast friends, and many coffees and conversations later we realized that we shared the same vision: to create a positive and supportive space where all women feel welcome and find clothing that makes them feel confident.

We chose The Sunroom as the name of our shop because we strive to create a warm, inviting atmosphere. We want everyone who walks through our doors to feel included and that feeling comes from offering a wide variety of styles to many sizes and body types, but most importantly it comes from Suzanne and myself. We strive to offer the best service, to always be honest,and gain the trust of our shoppers, and to create friendships with everyone who walks through our doors. People are our passion, and we're not just envisioning a clothing store, but a community space. 

What We Need & What You Get

We're striving to raise $15,000 to help us with operating and start-up costs including:

  • Remodeling/Rent. We have fallen in love with a retail space in the heart of Clintonville. It is in a high foot traffic area, and directly in-between two of our favorite places in the neighborhood: Dough Mama and Whits! The space has an interesting past (music studio turned massage parlor) and needs some interior renovations to make it right for us, but there is SO much potential. After removing the current floors, making everything ADA compliant, and slappin' on a fresh coat of paint, it will be ready to go! The extra funds will help facilitate these renovations. And once complete, the space will be able to host workshops, pop-up shops with other vendors, and many other gatherings. 
  • Product Ordering for Fall. We are taking out a small business loan and part of that capital is for our Spring/Summer orders. The sales from those goods will contribute greatly to our Fall merchandise, however in order to continue to grow our business we hope to expand our inventory and additional funding will play a large role in that.
  • Extra $ for Workshops and Community Gatherings! We are most excited about the positive impact our space will have on the Clintonville community. While planning our business we have received so much vital guidance from so many local business owners and it is very important to us that we pay that forward. We would love to be able to purchase items like folding chairs/tables and other event supplies so we can welcome as many members of the community as possible to our special events.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Just a moment of your time is appreciated so much, and if you find an opportunity to share our vision with someone if your life that would mean the world to us.

Thank you so much for your support,

XO,

Chloe + Suzanne

story:
Australia's only  NOT FOR PROFIT electricity retail company working for YOU and Not Shareholders to effectively SMASH the cost of electricity for your family.

All Aussies should have A life Time of True Value Electricity.

 

 

100% Australian Owned

We need your help to GO INTO BATTLE against  high priced electricity retailers. Aussie families have been ENSLAVED to high electricity prices for far too long.

United we will win the war against high priced electricity.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

$2million is our funding goal to pay the early stage start up costs.
                some of which are listed below.
Complex legal obligations to register with the Australian Energy
                Regulator and compliance with the National Energy Law and Rules

                [ Retail license $1.1 mil].
Australian Financial Services License.
Experienced Energy Consultants fees and ongoing cost.

What You Get
          You will be one of the first to have access to Low Cost Flat Rate Electricity saving you up to $300 per year.  

 You are the major benefactor for as little as $49.
             
The Impact

 

 New jobs for 35 people in the first year growing to over 150 jobs within 3 years.

Up to 10,000 families in the first year with savings of over $300  every year on their electricity bills.

A ripple must start some where Power 4 People will start retailing  in NSW first, then trading into most of Australia within 5 years. 

              
WHY POWER 4 PEOPLE?
 
All existing electricity retail companies are profit driven. 
They will charge you the customer a premium price for electricity.
Power 4 People is a NOT FOR PROFIT company and our only goal is to help you.
ENJOY A LIFE TIME OF TRUE VALUE ELECTRICITY with a 100% Australian owned company.
 

    Risks & Challenges

    To forget all the reasons why it won't work, instead believe in the one reason it will work :  "The Power 4 People Community" 
    This is the Challenge
    There has NEVER been a Not for Profit electricity retail company before.
    Believe in Power 4 People and make a difference today and please give generously.
    Click on BACK IT to donate today, we appreciate your donation.

    Please like and share our campaign with your family and friends, Donors like you make this possible.
    Visit our website at www.power4people.com.au
    Visit our Facebook page
     
    PS: Please don't delay your donation today really can make a difference.

story:
Our Home Space - More than just a market place

If you are viewing from a phone, clicking View Perks below will not let you see the images of the Perks. To do that you will have to scroll down in the Story section. After viewing you can click View Perks to get to the check-out. The clickable index does not work from most phones.

Another way to view our products is by simply clicking onto our website, have a look at the products there and then come back here to make your selection.

We know that it might take a few extra seconds, but hope that your will to help is strong enough for you to be able to put up with the little extra clicking that a crowdfunding campaign require.

Regardless wether we reach our funding goal or not, the products you select will be sent to you and 70-75% will go towards helping the Huni Kuin!

 

Short summary

The web portal Our Home Space is being set up with this campaign.

We are a start up company that will leverage eco and fair products for social change starting with a project for clean water and better living conditions for the Huni Kuin people of the Amazonas.

We are guided by our vision and mission.

We accept donations in this campaign but our objective is to offer goods in exchange for your help. Just a bit further below is a list of perks that we offer to backers. Or simply put, items you can give as gifts! You can also find them on the right side of this page if you are viewing through a browser.

We will, with Your help, be able to buy and bring water LifeStraw family purification units to the Huni Kuin people of the Amazon to prevent deaths of their young.

We have, by invitation of the Huni Kuin, started to develop strategies for improving their living conditions. Here is a description of what we will do besides giving them immidiate relief by supplying water filters.

The idea is pretty basic, we sell products (and at really good prices too) and use the majority of our profit for humanitarian causes. This way, if you don't have money to donate, you can simply continue consuming goods like you probably would anyway if you are likely to buy a pair of trousers, a T-shirt, a dress or jewelry the coming 6 months, or a christmas gift for someone, and still be able to help us achieve our aim of saving lives by you making a conscious decision when shopping.

No matter if we are able to fund the entire amount that we set as a goal, we will make sure that about 70-75% of our profit goes to water purification units and that you get the products you choose plus a Christmas card that you can give to the person you have bought it for (even if it is for yourself)!

Directly below you will find a presentation highlighting the most important aspects of our campaign. Click the topics you wan't to know more about or simply start scrolling.

And remember, if you like our idea and want to contribute but don't have money, please share it, you might know many who might be able to help. 

Enjoy!

Table of contents

1. What you get for helping - The products

1.1. All is one Clothing

1.2. Huni Kuin Crafts

1.3. Raven + Lily

1.4. EYESEEi

2. What is this crowdfunding campaign for?

Our Home Space - a platform for conscious consumption

3. What will we do concretely with this first project?

Our first crowdfunding project - PRODUCTS FOR CLEAN WATER

2.1 Aim of the project

4. Other Ways You Can Help

5. What We Need to make this a reality - Budget

5.1. Permaculture

5.2 Opportunities

6. What is Our Home Space?

6.1 Vision

6.2 Mission

6.3 Business Idea

7. Background - Why the Amazon?

8. So who am I?

 

 

1. What you get for helping - The products

Below you will find our 4 categories of perks. You can of course also donate directly to the project. Regardless of which option you choose you will be able to follow the process of implementation via video, text and images on our webpage.

If you choose any of these items as persk we will be able to make sure that we can send water filtration units to the jungle so that you can help us save lives this rainy season.

Your products will arrive a bit later via post in Feb/March 2017. But you will get a postcard with the product, saying that you choose to save lives in time for Christmas, showing the product of your choice. So that you can either send that via mail or print it out and give it to the person you have in mind for your gift.

Now isn't that for good value for your money? You are able to give life by making an active choice in shopping, and the most important thing, we would like to add, is that we will be able to fund this project and you will help save the lives of several young children. And that my friends, is worth way more than the contents of any of the perks. That's a gift for life, literary.

So may we recommend that you give this as a Christmas gift to someone you love this season (Yes, it is ok to give it to yourself, its good if you love yourself too). It feels good to help, so we are helping you to feel good about helping us help the Huni Kuin.

 

Note: Taxes and custom fees might be charged by your local carrier or post office when you pick up your perks.

 

back to top

1.1. All is one Clothing

With this crowdfunding campaign we are not only launching our new venture Our Home Space but also our own brand, All is One, as part of our strategy to secure funds for the achievement of our goals.

All is One focuses on basic wear, things that we generally use a bit more often which leads to more stress on the environment than other products that aren't produced in the same quantity world wide. If we can catch part of the global production of these items, making it fair trade, organic and in an environmentally friendly process, we would be proud. Plus, we would be able to direct the funds towards achieving our vision.

All products are Fair wear and all products are organic cotton, except for our trousers which are Fair wear only at the moment.

However if we reach 300 pairs of trousers selected as perks, then we will be able to make it fair trade and organic! Sweet right?

So if you want the trousers in organic cotton, be sure to share our campaign and let people know that if we reach high enough quantities on them they will be organic.

But dont forget, they are Fair wear at the moment, and that means that they are produced under ethical circumstances with fair wages to the workers in non-toxic environments and with no polluted water going out untreated from the factories. Now that's not bad.

No logos are visible when worn. Because making a fashion statement isn’t necessarily about what you see on the outside.

All is One - Men's V-neck T-shirt

Final products might differ slightly from images.

€34 Men's T-shirt - Organic and Fair wear / fair trade
V-neck T-shirt in soft organic cotton. Twin needle stitching to hem and sleeves for extra strength. 

 

All is One - Women's V-neck T-shirt

Final products might differ slightly from images.

€34 Women's T-shirt - Organic and Fair wear / fair trade
V-neck T-shirt that features a V that is not too deep and a slightly curved hem for a better look. The cut is a medium cut so is not figure hugging. 1x1 rib collar and a taped back neck with bind stitching to hem and sleeves. 

 

All is One - Women's scoop neck T-shirt

Final products might differ slightly from images.

€34 Women's scoop neck T-shirt -Organic and Fair wear / fair trade
Made from organic cotton . It has a narrow 1x1 rib collar on the neckline and the bottom hem has a slight curve, making a great looking shirt. 

 

All is One - Women's chino trousers

Final products might differ slightly from images.

€60 Women's Chinos 7/8 length - Fair wear with the possibility of it becoming organic

Flat front. Zip fly with button over. Belt loops. 7/8 length.
Two rear mock jetted pockets.
98% cotton twill/2% elastane.

 

All is One - Men's chino trousers

Final products might differ slightly from images.

€60 Men's Chinos - Fair wear with the possibility of it becoming organic

Flat front. Belt loops. Zip fly with button over. Two side pockets.
Front ticket pocket. Two rear jetted pockets.
98% cotton twill/2% elastane.

 

All is One - Organic Tote bag

 

€18 Tote bag - Organic and Fair wear
Carry/shoulder straps (55 cm long).
37 x 42 cm. Capacity 15.5 litres.

back to top

1.2. Huni Kuin Crafts

These perks are made by the Huni Kuin tribe. By choosing items in this category you help them to an income and support fair pay for work done in the villages helping us achieve the goal of positive social change.

Since there are so many different types of patterns, and because it is all handmade, what you get is actually a coupon for the perk you selected.

This way you can browse through all the products in the category on our page after we recieve the goods and choose the right one for You. This ensures you get the version you want and that money goes directly to the tribe, plus they get clean water.

€44 Bracelet
€88 2 bracelets, matching pair

€40 Small Huni Kuin Bag

€50 Huni Kuin Necklace

All Huni Kuin jewelry and bags are made by women of the tribe and are the result of a project of valuing the traditional knowledge of indigenous women of the Huni Kuin people. The project enables the meeting of more than 50 women in order to promote the exchange of knowledge among the oldest and most qualified artisans with the future generations of women of the 32 villages of the indigenous land that they inhabit, located in the Amazon forest.

In addition to empowering indigenous women, the project aims to promote greater distribution of income acquired through the sale of ethnic art of this people, since in most cases only the families of the leaderships that travel outside the forest end up benefiting.

At the moment the project is creating a label to operate and sell from so that not only will you get a piece of original handmade jewelry, you will also get a note from the person who did where that informs of the meaning of the sacred geometry of your specific piece. The project is managed by Deborah Castor, from Rio de Janeiro, and funded by donations.

back to top

  

We have also chosen to collaborate with some brilliant initiatives on the market for some of the perks so that everyone will be able to find something they want. These perks come from brands that make a difference. These will not be issued as discount coupons as in the case with the Huni Kuin crafts but will be sent to you directly just like you ordered it.

back to top

1.3. Raven + Lily

Raven + Lily was created to alleviate poverty among women. They currently help employ over 1,500 marginalized women at fair trade wages to give them access to a safe job, sustainable income, health care, education, and a real chance to break the cycle of poverty for themselves and their families. Raven + Lily is committed to providing beautiful and unique modern minimalist products that are made by hand, follow fair trade standards, and honor their eco-friendly commitment.

Read more about the inspiring story of Raven + Lily on their webpage. 

 

Ming Wrap Drape Dress

€90 

Product Description
From Raven+Lily, a wrap dress that creates a relaxed and sophisticated look for an evening out. The dresses are made of repurposed remnant jersey in a zero-waste facility located in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. This partnership empowers women to break the cycle of poverty and provide for their families. 

Sizes: XS/S/M/L
Care + Maintenance: Eco-dry or spot clean; store folded flat (do not hang)
Color: Black and Dark Grey

The Story Behind This Product

Where was it made?:
Empowering at risk women in Phnom Penh in a zero-waste facility to break the cycle of poverty and provide for their families.

How was it made?:
Eco-friendly apparel made with re-purposed remnant jersey with exclusive hand-screened designs

back to top

1.4. EYESEEi

 

 

EYESEEi was founded by Swedish fashion designer Sanna Aulén in 2013. Before she created EYESEEi, Sanna studied and worked with clothing in the global fashion industry, longing to create items that she could connect with in a more sustainable and meaningful way to underline the slow fashion movement she wanted to be part of.  

Sanna works with transparent production, and in Bali she works directly with a few select silver smiths. All items are handmade in natural materials by local silversmiths making these items in the comfort of their own village and home, always with fair trading in mind and a personal contact directly with the maker. 

EYESEEi works partly with recycled silver, and with silver from unsold jewelry through a company that recreates Sterling silver purchased from other local artisans. Silver  can be transformed and reused countless times.

Link to EYESEEi's webpage.

 

Triangle pin earring

€40
Unique crystal pin earring with one handpicked, rough cut clear quart set in sterling silver with Italian chain.

To provide a unique and special look all of our jewelry are handmade and our stones are rough cut or kept raw. Variations in size, color and texture occurs.

 

SKY RING

€39
Amethyst pyramid ring in recycled Sterling silver and with Amethyst crystal.

Variations in size, color and texture may occur.

Sizes (US):
6 (16,5mm diameter)
7  (17,3mm diameter)
8 (18,0mm diameter)
9 (18,9mm diameter)
10

 

Connection ring

€25
Handmade ring in recycled Sterling silver.
Adjustable in 2 different base sizes 7 & 9 (US). 
All rings are hand made and small variations in size, colour and shape may occur.

 

Triangle earrings

€26
A pair of handmade facetted triangle earrings in 925 silver. 
Small variations in size, color and texture may occur.

 

Triangle ring

€26
Handmade double triangle ring in 925 silver. 
Adjustable base size 7 (US).
Small variations in size, color and texture may occur.

 

Drop ring

€30
Handmade drop shaped ring in sterling silver.
Sizes feels bigger because the tip of the drop created extra space.
Small variations in shape may occur.

Sizes (US):
6 (16,5mm diameter)
7  (17,3mm diameter)
8 (18,0mm diameter)
9 (18,9mm diameter)
10

back to top

2. Our Home Space
- a platform for conscious consumption

The web portal Our Home Space is being set up with this campaign. The goal of the page is to enable us to initiate and/or sponsor community projects that empower locals to improve their lives in parts of the world where we see how we easily, with the help of our allies* can make a positive change in the life of a community.

One such easy way is helping to ensure that there is clean water available when most needed.

The idea behind Our Home Space is to leverage products for social change. Instead of just asking people to contribute with money for a humanitarian cause, we offer products in return. It's called selling (I believe you have heard about it before). We use sales as a means to stimulate social change by selling things people buy regardless of whether we sell them or not. But by buying it from us, the consumer makes a conscious decision. Conscious Consumption. And to show you how that works we offer perks that match the value of your contribution in this campaign.

And of course, we don't just offer any products, but products that are made by brilliant people who have ensured that their production process is not only non-detrimental to our world or the people making them, but that the production and distribution helps workers to better living conditions. We also offer products that are made by communities that have no access to the international market, or any other market for that matter. We also offer products from small scale artisans who either manufacture themselves or work closely with the people making their goods, ensuring that the pay is fair. And by allowing us to sell their products from our platform they are helping our cause.

The goal is to offer ecological and ethically produced products that are part of everyday life. We are starting this campaign with clothes and jewelry but will eventually have a wider selection of products.

What this means for you, our ally* is that you can rest assured that anything you buy on Our Home Space will benefit people in more than one step of the way from design, production and sales.

To make it easier for our allies to be well informed when buying from us you will see what level of social, ethical and ecological consideration the product takes in its creation process and thus you can be better informed in your decision.

*Ally – Term that we use for our customers, because based on their/your decision to consume consciously we simply cannot use the old wear and tear term ‘consumer’.

back to top

3. Our first crowdfunding project - PRODUCTS FOR CLEAN WATER

The first project that we are working on at the moment, this very project that you are reading about here on Indiegogo, is a clean water project in the Brazilian part of the Amazon, on the border of Peru where the Huni Kuin people live.

Currently many of the young and old die each rainy season due to drinking and washing themselves with contaminated water. The contamination occurs due to heavy rainfall that stirs up all sorts of debris, feces, dead animals etc. from the ground of the forest and washes it down into the rivers which are the main and only source of water for the tribes living there.

We aim to bring at least 40 Lifestraw Family units with us to distribute to families with young children who are in risk of getting sick and dying. One lifestraw family unit can provide a family with 18 000 liters (7 755 gallons) of clean potable water. That is 3 years of water consumption for a family of 5.

 
A second aim is to purify water on site, with locally sourced materials so that they won't be dependent on outsiders buying and bringing filters or purification modules.

Also, we will be looking at implementing new ways of making toilets in a way so that they do not overflow and contaminate the rivers during rainy season.

This will be achieved through a permaculture initiative that you can read more about by clicking this link.

Concept image by Artur Moustafa - Our Home Space.

back to top

3.1 Aim of the project

The first aim of the project is to make sure that the people of the tribe have access to clean water to prevent deaths amongst its young population as soon as possible. That’s why the project time is set to 19 days. So that we will have time to go there with LifeStraws in the beginning of the rainy season. The campaign ends on Christmas eve and our hope is that by then we will have good news for the people of the village.

(Image from the company behind LifeStraw. As you can see, even here there is an extra benefit baked into your backing, not only do the children in the Amazon get clean water, children in Africa will enjoy the same benefit!)

An extension of the first goal with this water project, as mentioned above, is to find many ways to make sure that the tribe has access to clean potable water now and in the future.

In addition to the tasks outlined in the permaculture project we will also work with making activated carbon for filters that can be made on site. Experiments with this was started last year and we believe it can be made with lime peel for carbon and lime juice (yes, sounds weird but it works) as the active corrosive ingredient. The reason for using lime is because they grow it around the villages. Activated carbon that has been used in filters can later be mixed with earth and food waste to create terra preta, the most fertile soil to be found. Terra Preta is a possible offshoot benefit of the activated carbon part of the project, as the soil which the tribes use to grow their crops on is poor on nutrients and does not yield for long stretches of time, making the locals have to clear new areas of land with fire for growing crops, a process that releases CO2 into the atmosphere. And we want to keep the trees in the Amazon because of the obvious C02 effect, if for nothing else, as trees transform C02 to oxygen. And creating terra preta actually helps to bind C02 from the atmosphere into the ground. Making terra preta was common practice in the pre-Colombian civilizations of the Amazon and was key to being able to sustain larger communities in the Amazonian jungle.

To start the project we will however as stated above, first make sure that we are able to help from day one that we arrive there by buying and bringing award winning Life Straw Family units that can give families with children 18 000 liters of potable water per unit (price €105 per unit). LifeStraw removes virtually all bacteria (99.9999 percent), protozoan parasites (99.99 percent) and viruses (99.999 percent) that can contaminate water. We aim at bringing at least 40 Lifestraws Family units with us. If the funding exceeds our goal then all the better. We will be able to bring more units and have cash with us to sponsor projects that seem to be going in the right direction.

We are starting this campaign as a means to collect enough funds for us to be able to go to the Amazon to give this much needed aid and then to start the project of making rainwater harvest and purification units together with the locals in Altamira. Once we have positive test results from our water samples we will be inviting people from other villages to come and learn how to replicate the model. 

The long term goal with the water project is to find many suitable ways to purify water on site, with local materials. This way we can turn it into a part of the culture, to harvest water and make wells instead of relying on the polluted rivers as the only source of water.

If we are able to secure enough funds to secure clean water with this campaign we will go ahead with our next step which aims at eliminating the use of diesel for electricity. And in the long run, eliminate the need for diesel powered motors for their boats, powering them with stored solar energy.

Fossil fuels is a trap for these people as it is a cost to transport diesel along the rivers using diesel. And so because of their very limited income, sometimes they are stranded in one place, waiting for someone to earn money so that they can buy fuel. 

At the moment it is simply not possible for them to save any money at all to buy solar cells/photovoltaic cells, and batteries. That will be the second phase for Our Home Space. Diverting our income towards the placement of solar panels and batteries in the villages. So that they can save their earnings and perhaps buy more solar panels for other villages.

 

After having secured energy through renewable sources we will buy computers, cameras and sound equipment for the school and create a controlled (something with walls) environment where there is both energy and clean water and where those who are sick can get treated without having to be out in the open, not having to worry about poisonous animals and insects. Adjacent to this building we will have another controlled environment, a plant school, so that they can grow crops that normally wouldn’t make it past the sprouting stage outside because of insects and other animals. This stage is to ensure that they have access to food all year round and don’t have to buy this from the outside.

If the model we are thinking of for the above mentioned phases work out, we will be able to be part of a movement that can eliminate the use of fossil fuels in the Amazon and allows the tribes to once again be self-sufficient yet connected to the world. Yes, it sounds ambitious, but it can done. But only if someone starts. And luckily, there is a few of us on the ground. And now we are reaching out to You to become our allies.

But first, we want to do what we can to prevent deaths among the young population of the Huni Kuin during this and the three coming rainy seasons.

back to top

4. Other Ways You Can Help

Do you like the idea but can't afford our products? Please share it on social networks.

You like the idea but not the products? Buy it for a hippie friend of yours, the will love you!

Or simply donate. 

back to top

5. What We Need to make this a reality

Here are some more numbers for you to see how your shopping can actually help someone. 

The campaign is set to flexible funding. This means that even if we don't reach the funding goal we will be able to use what we were able to raise towards implementing our vision. If we miss the goal we will not compromise on the perks that we will send out to our backers but instead we will look at how we can still deliver what we will afford. Regardless of the amount of funds raised 70-75% of the profit will go towards delivering water purification to the Huni Kuin. It is too important to risk not doing just because we might not reach all the way. So since there is a will there is a way. 

 

We set our goal at €26,000.  If we use this as en example for how much funds we will be able to raise then the budget for this project will be as follows: 

 

€12,220 is what it costs for us to buy, pay customs and deliver all the products that we will send to you as tokens of our gratitude. 

The rest, what comes below is what normally goes as 'profit' when doing the numbers for a regular business, but this is where we show how will spend the money differently than as a regular shop would.

 

€2,970 goes to buying LifeStraw Family units. That gives 40 units each capable of purifying 18,000 liters of water. That is 720,000 Liters of purified water. Enough to get 40 families through this and the coming 3 rainy seasons. But remember. What we are really hoping to accomplish here is to create on site water purification with locally sourced materials that can not only be taught, but also replicated and taught to other villages and tribes. This would ensure clean water for a lot longer than those 40 units can. This alongside with the permaculture initiative will help alleviate living conditions in the area immensely.

We will however try to get LifeStraw units cheaper in order to maximise efforts. This might be achieved by selling Lifestraw units on our webpage. Discussions about acting as a retailer of their products have started.

€3,826 goes to equipment and sponsoring the permaculture project in the village. More detailed budget found under section 5.1.

€3,300 of the total profit goes to travel and transport for Artur, Pia and the Lifestraw units. After all, if we can't go there then we can't deliver the items. They live as far into the Amazon as you can imagine.

€2,600 10% of what we are able to raise covers fees for Indiegogo and Paypal.

€1,084 is profit. It is for us to cover expenses whilst there in the jungle and to compensate for any loss of income that we would have had if we were not working with this project. It is for us to be able to eat, sleep (in a home) and get about. And it is for building our website and operations.

That's 7,87% of the earnings for us. That is a bad business idea if the idea is to become wealthy. But that is not the idea here, so don't worry. The idea is to be able to help. 

The benchmark number for any charity is to spend less than 33.3% of their total income on anything else than the charitable cause. Well we are pretty proud to say that we are within those limits. However we are not a charity (who knows what we will be in the future) but we are a socially conscious company that uses a pattern that already exists, that almost everyone does (buying goods), and use the profit to fund projects we find worth wile.

 

If we are able to fund the entire project, and get even more funds. Then 20% of that extra income will go towards buying more LifeStraw family units.

And another 40% will go to supporting and initiating other projects in the village. Like the Permaculture initiative. We will find a way to get better equipment so that we can make sure that the permaculture project can be implemented faster and perhaps in more places.

The remaining 40% will have to go to upscale our operations to be able to handle the new size of the project. Half of the extra income of these 40% will go towards paying hours to consultants or hiring in-house staff. 20% will go to office costs, services etc. and 30% will go to research and development, looking at ways to best fulfil the goals of the organization.

back to top

5.1. Permaculture

"Permaculture is a system of agricultural and social design principles centered on simulating or directly utilizing the patterns and features observed in natural ecosystems. 

It has many branches that include but are not limited to ecological design, ecological engineering, environmental design, construction and integrated water resources management that develops sustainable architecture, and regenerative and self-maintained habitat and agricultural systems modeled from natural ecosystems."

Concept image by Artur Moustafa - Our Home Space.

Since it is within our vision and mission to sponsor initiatives and projects that have the same aim as us at Our Home Space, we have partnered with a permaculture initiative that share many goals with us.

Thus we will be able to achieve our goals by helping with the funding of ongoing initiatives. Simply put, through collaboration.

One such initiative is called PERMACULTURE IN THE VILLAGES. It is currently in need of funding for implementation to be possible. They have however secured funds for salaries and air-plane tickets for 3 out of 4 workers through a yearly festival, the Nixpu Pima festival, where people from outside the forest come and pay a sum to participate with the tribe. This is the very same festival where we will be handing out LifeStraw Family units once our funding goals are achieved.

So at the moment we need funds for the fourth worker as well as funds for tools and material for implementation to be possible. Thus we have budgeted €3.850 of our raised funds for tools and materials to complete this project.

If we go beyond our funding goals we will also make sure that the fourth worker can get paid, speeding up the process considerably.

Click here for a fuller description of the project by Hilas Mariante Al Khouri (to the left on the image below ), from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

 

back to top

5.2. Opportunities

We already have some promising opportunities both when it comes to implementation and expansion.

Sponsoring on Photo Voltaic film covered glass panels

We are currently in discussions with a large supplier of glass for photo voltaic cells on the possibillity of sponsorship by displaying their name and making their products available and known through our implementation phase. The more views we get on the videos we post during implementation, the more likeley we are to get a full sponsorship on this.

 

Expanding to other biotopes

We are in discussions with a Tibetan Buddhist monastery in southern India who are interested in making a transition into self-sustanence so that they can work as a hub for the tibetan community in the region. 

 

back to top

6. What is Our Home Space?

Our Home Space, is as mentioned above, a platform for conscious consumption with the aim of helping to establish at least one self-sustaining village in the Amazon. Here are our vision and mission statements alongside our business idea.

(Concept image depicting Voltaic film covered glass panels on a geodesic dome for a plant school that provides energy and harvests rainwater. Concept image by Artur Moustafa - Our Home Space.)

6.1 Vision

We see a possible future where many initiatives and ways of self-sustenance co-exist and learn from each other. We believe that a possible way towards this can be found in using our current system (while it exists) to finance and develop this. So that regardless of whether our outside world stands or not, these places will. And they can have everything they need regardless of our rise or fall. Our vision is to help make sure these places exist in all biotopes.

The vision of Our Home Space is that by turning one village in the middle of the Amazon into a self-sustainable village that meets the needs of all of its inhabitants we can find ways to make sure that the model can spread to other villages surrounding it ushering a system with nodes that support each other but that can function by themselves.Once we have found a model that works for the tropical jungle, we will look at other biotopes and how we can achieve self-sufficiency together with the people who live there.e at Our Home Space know that the technology to achieve this exists today. Our vision is that we will aid in finding economic solutions that allows for the distribution of the right solution to the right place so that we all can enjoy our home space.

 

6.2 Mission

The mission of Our Home Space is to, with the help of our allies*, aid with the development of at least one self-sustaining community that can be said to be outside the global economy.

Our mission is to make it in such a way that the model is replicable.

We will be working towards ensuring that the following criteria is met in every area where we involve ourselves.

  • Access to clean potable water
  • Access to renewable energy
  • Self-sufficiency in food
  • A place for learning with access to global communications
  • A place to be able to produce and sell goods to the global and local market

Our Home Space will share all functional findings and strategies openly, as instruction videos, documentation through text and image, classes and workshops and by offering access to all tools used and developed.

6.3 BUSINESS IDEA

Our business idea is to supply customers with ethically and ecologically produced goods that we know people consume anyway (because of the set-up of the world economic system), such as, but not limited to, t-shirts, underwear, trousers and socks etc. at competitive prices. We will be retailing both our own brands and those of others who we see fit with the model of Our Home Space.

And for us to be able to reach out to as many allies as possible we have tailored our own brand, All is One, to be modest in style, color and prints. Because making a fashion statement isn’t necessarily about what you see on the outside.

back to top

7. Background

 

 

In October 2014 I, Artur, fell ill with Meningitis and in my search of getting better, after having been met by nonchalance from my doctors, I met someone through a friend. My friend was travelling with a shaman from the Amazon by the name of Ixa. Ixa told me he could help me get well and invited me to come to his village in the Amazon. Having spent three days with him I was not doubting that he could indeed live up to what he had said and so a few months later I found myself on the way to his village.

I spent quite some time there, carrying with me my lifestraw to allow me to drink water from the river. I mean this is as deep in the jungle as you can get so there is no infrastructure there to speak of. The rivers are the roads and also the only source of water for these people. Ixa showed me the vast treasures of plant medicines that he has learnt about since he was three years old and with time something miraculous happened. About one year after I had first fallen ill I had my first pain free day.

Not only was I free of pain. I had regained the physical and mental strength I once had taken for granted.

So here I was. Witnessing the lives of the Huni Kuin tribe from within, hearing Ixa and the other villagers telling me about their lives there.And since the rainy season was approaching, I was informed that 9 children in this village alone had died during the past rainy season. I had my lifestraw, but what did they have? The rivers?

Well during the rainy season the entire forest is completely washed over with rain for days on end, bringing with it all sorts of debris, feces, dead animals, bacteria and parasites into the rivers.

Ixa told me that one reason for having opened up their lands for visitors, participating in their festival and taking part of their culture and knowledge was because they needed help and were inviting us to come up with ideas to help them. I started thinking about how I could help them realize their goals.

I reasoned that it would be better to harvest rainwater before it got in contact with the rivers and so back to my normal self I started designing a rainwater harvesting module that I saw could be done with local materials and implemented on every house.

Working conditions were not optimal so I decided to make a workbench to quicken my work as my time there was running out. I promised myself that I would be back to complete my project.

That of finding a suitable way to purify water on site with local materials. Something that they themselves could make and integrate into their culture to prevent the deaths of their young and old.

 

The Huni Kuin, as are many inhabitants of the Amazon, are carriers of ancient knowledge that only recently has started to make its entry into western society but with major impact on our quality of life with about 25% of our medicines having their origins in the rainforest.

At the same time western society and its needs account for rainforest destruction to such a magnitude that it kills about 137 plant, animal and insect species every day.

Most shamans, those who carry the accumulated wisdom of thousands of years of predecessors are over 70 years old and don’t have apprentices. This means that their vast knowledge is slipping out of human consciousness as their way of life gives way to western values, which in the end values the amazon based on timber and mining prices.

Before the rainforests covered 14% of the world’s surface it is now down to less than 6%. A trend which simply isn’t sustainable in a world with rising CO2 levels.

 

Today the people of this village go to the nearest village with riverboats run by diesel motors where they besides food, buy more diesel to power generators in their own villages.

This means that the little income they have from selling arts and crafts go to waste on fossil fuels further polluting the lungs of the world, not because they want to, but because they are trapped in a system created by others.

What struck me when I was there was that all of this is unnecessary. They could easily have everything they need to be self-sufficient with some minor help from the outside. Since they can be considered as living outside the global economic system there is no way for them to buy equipment to make solar powered water wells, solar panels, batteries or anything else needed to become self-sufficient by themselves in enough quantities unless something is changed.

And we can do that with them.

If their money didn’t have to go to fuel and food grown with pesticides in remote places they would be able to direct that money to a nearby community so that they too would be able to become self-reliant.

If they were allowed to reach out to a greater audience with their knowledge, story and craft they would be able to make a living.

So in the forest, I did not only think of what I could do, but what other people like me could contribute to in order to make sure that the world will be able to take part of the vast knowledge of the forest. 

At the moment they are looking for better living conditions. And they are looking at what is close at hand. Whilst in our part of the world we are looking beyond what we have today. There are countless initiatives on making self-sustaining communities in the developed world so there is no doubt that this will be achieved sooner or later.

And here it is possible because we operate within the global market. We can afford it. There will be business that find a way to give you free energy because it means that they can place energy producing units on your house and sell the surplus back to the grid. Out there, there is no grid and so there is no money to be made in the same business model.

We see many benefits with helping them with their tasks. For starters, losing their way of life will simply be too much of a loss for the world. And so we are looking at non-orthodox economic models to make sure that they can benefit from existing solutions in the world so that the world in turn can gain benefit from their knowledge and a healthy Amazonas for times to come. We are after all one humanity sharing this one world.

back to top

8. So who am I?

I mean, you don't just want your goods but you want to know that we will be able to deliver the project promised, right? 

Well, here is the good thing about bringing LifeStraw units. Even if my communication and teaching/learning skills are poor, they will still have access to 540,000 liters of purified water!

Other than that I(Artur) once started and ran a furniture company called VUJJ. We were awarded and nominated for a few prices, mainly for us putting focus on sustainable and durable production with storytelling. Something that was new in the furniture industry in 2006 when we first started. But then I realized what it really meant for me that there were more chairs in the world than people and so I went on to greener pastures thinking there must be a better cause for me to apply my creativity to. Some of those products are still produced today by rvw.se.


Image from part of Vujj's showroom in 2007.

I then went to London to work for an NGO, CLEAR-Village, working with developing concepts and methods for rapid project planning and implementation within the field of sustainable urban development.

I've been a speaker at various sustainability conferences talking from the perspective of an entrepreneur and designer. One such instance was the Sustainability conference '08 in Malmö hosted by the Centre for Sustainable Design, Farnham, UK. Below is a video with thoughts on sustainable design from 2008, expressed by a young and rather camera shy version of me.

 

After that I used those models when I started working as a project manager at the Helsingborg city Theatre, where I worked with theatre as a tool for achieving social cohesion. Something that also lifted the ticket sales of the theatre.

 

When I started the project sales were hanging around 30% and the image of the theatre in the city was dark. Facts I was oblivious to as I started my outreach project. After my four years at the theatre we were up to over 90% in sales and the project had not only won accolade from the main funders, Region Skåne - Kultur and the Swedish Arts Council, but had also received attention from The European commission who used the project as a best practice project for OMC, Open Method of Communication, a way for member countries to share best practice.

Here is a video  of recommendation from my former employer at Helsingborg city Theatre.

 
 

At the end of my time at the theatre, before becoming the theatre manager at a theatre for children, I helped establish the performing arts biennial Bibu in the town of Helsingborg. 

After that I worked as a theatre manager at Teater Sagohuset. Unfortunately, during my time there I got an inflammation in either my brain or my spine which left me unable to work for more than a year, struggling with constant pain, fatigue, loss of balance, words and many other abilities. It was during this time that I first met the Huni Kuin tribe, and with their ancient knowledge, I was able to restore my body to a functional state. 

Here is a link to my design page with CV and reference projects

&

Here is a link to my personal page.

But all of this is what I have done before. Now I have the chance to be the person who brings your help to people who need it. I have been able to accomplish things before, and the reason for this section to be here is for you to have confidence in me being able to accomplish this project as well, but this time, with Your help.

And yes, there is a possibillity that the funding goal won't be reached or that the ambitions of helping to make them a self-reliant thriving community won't be reached with the help of this initiative. But I can only see one thing worse than that, and that is not even trying.

back to top

All is one ClothingWith this crowdfunding campaign we are not only launching our new venture Our Home Space but also our own brand, All is One, as part of our strategy to secure funds for the achievement of our goals.All is One focuses on basic wear, things that we generally use a bit more often which leads to more stress on the environment than other products that aren't produced in the same quantity world wide. Huni Kuin CraftsThese perks are made by the Huni Kuin tribe. By choosing items in this category you help them to an income and support fair pay for work done in the villages helping us achieve the goal of positive social change.Since there are so many different types of patterns, and because it is all handmade, what you get is actually a coupon for the perk you selected.This way you can browse through all the products in the category on our page after we recieve the goods and choose the right one for You. This ensures you get the version you want and that money goes directly to the tribe, plus they get clean water.€44 Bracelet€88 2 bracelets, matching pair€40 Small Huni Kuin Bag€50 Huni Kuin NecklaceAll Huni Kuin jewelry and bags are made by women of the tribe and are the result of a project of valuing the traditional knowledge of indigenous women of the Huni Kuin people. The project enables the meeting of more than 50 women in order to promote the exchange of knowledge among the oldest and most qualified artisans with the future generations of women of the 32 villages of the indigenous land that they inhabit, located in the Amazon forest.In addition to empowering indigenous women, the project aims to promote greater distribution of income acquired through the sale of ethnic art of this people, since in most cases only the families of the leaderships that travel outside the forest end up benefiting.At the moment the project is creating a label to operate and sell from so that not only will you get a piece of original handmade jewelry, you will also get a note from the person who did where that informs of the meaning of the sacred geometry of your specific piece. The project is managed by Deborah Castor, from Rio de Janeiro, and funded by donations.back to top  We have also chosen to collaborate with some brilliant initiatives on the market for some of the perks so that everyone will be able to find something they want. These will not be issued as discount coupons as in the case with the Huni Kuin crafts but will be sent to you directly just like you ordered it.back to top1.3. Raven + LilyRaven + Lily was created to alleviate poverty among women. They currently help employ over 1,500 marginalized women at fair trade wages to give them access to a safe job, sustainable income, health care, education, and a real chance to break the cycle of poverty for themselves and their families. Raven + Lily is committed to providing beautiful and unique modern minimalist products that are made by hand, follow fair trade standards, and honor their eco-friendly commitment.Read more about the inspiring story of Raven + Lily on their webpage.  Ming Wrap Drape Dress€90 Product DescriptionFrom Raven+Lily, a wrap dress that creates a relaxed and sophisticated look for an evening out. EYESEEi  EYESEEi was founded by Swedish fashion designer Sanna Aulén in 2013. Before she created EYESEEi, Sanna studied and worked with clothing in the global fashion industry, longing to create items that she could connect with in a more sustainable and meaningful way to underline the slow fashion movement she wanted to be part of.  Sanna works with transparent production, and in Bali she works directly with a few select silver smiths. All items are handmade in natural materials by local silversmiths making these items in the comfort of their own village and home, always with fair trading in mind and a personal contact directly with the maker. EYESEEi works partly with recycled silver, and with silver from unsold jewelry through a company that recreates Sterling silver purchased from other local artisans.
